 NICARAGUA RURAL MUNICIPALITIES PROJECT ANNEX 1 BACKGROUND: THE POLICY AND INSTITUTIONAL CONTEXT FOR DECENTRALIZATION " 1. RATIONALE FOR DECENTRALIZATION Rationale for Decentralization. Decentralization of decision-making and responsibility to the local level is considered an imnportant element in improving rural development programs and natural resource management; a perception shared by government, NGOs and foreign donors. This derives from the extreme weakness in the mechanisms which exist to ensure that public investments are efficient and consistent with rural development and natural resource management potentials at the local level. Where contemplated, municipal-level priorities and opportunities have been limited to diagnostics and consultations usually carried out by central GON agencies or outside programs rather than through ongoing dialogue and shared responsibility. Thus, the distribution of resources and investment activities heavily reflect central government priorities.'2 In contrast, the principle underlying decentralization is that national priorities be satisfied through incentives and broad thematic and zonal targeting of investmnent resources and local mechanisms be preferred for their specific disposition. Local governments are closer to the people and problems that result from poverty and often also from resource degradation and hence internalize those costs better and more rationally prioritize the use of scarce investment resources. In the limited instances where "local choice" mechanisms have been functioning in Nicaragua the results are generally positive. The GTZ/INIFOM Proyecto de Fortalacimiento de la Autonomia Municipal (FAMU) is one exarnple, and the SIDA/INIFOM development programs for infrastructure and community works in pern-urban poverty zones is another.!3- There is also an expanding body of evidence elsewhere on the advantages of decentralized rural development solutions, several of which are being supported by the World Bank in LAC, for example in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia and Mexico. I/ For a more complete treatment of the subject, see Project Working Papers: (3) "Capacidad de Las Municipalidades "; (4) "Capacidad de Las Organizaciones No Gubernamentales "; (25) "Fondos Municipales Para El Manejo y Conservacidn de Los Recursos Naturales"; (16) "Programa de Generaci6n y Transferencia de Tecnologia Para el Manejo Sostenible de Recursos Naturales"; (28) "Reglamento Interno - Proyecto PROTIERRA; (18) "Demanda de Microproyectos "; 'Asignaci6n de Recursos Para Inversirn Municipales", 'Municipal Funds", 'Municipal Finances and Decentralization" 2' Implementation capacity, in terms of NGO and government's human resources also shows a "lumpy" distribution in response to donor financing. (Abaunza, B.M., 1993. Las Organizaciones No Gubernamentales En La Generaci6n y Transferencia de Tecnologia, pg. 12). 3' The immaturity of existing examples makes impossible useful comparisons of the efficiency of centralized vs decentralized models in Nicaragua, however, neither is it clear that such analysis will be pertinent. Given that macroeconomic and public sector restructuring policies demand a diminished role for central government the creation, implementation and strengthening of decentralized mechanisms is unavoidable.
 Annex 1 Background: The Policy and Institutional Context for Decentralization Page 2 of 17 2. THE LEGAL FRAMEWORK Local Government. The legal framework of municipal governments is included in the Constitution, the Electoral Law, the Municipal Law, the Law of Political Administrative Division and the regulations on the Organization and Operation of Municipalities, approved by executive decree. The foundation for local government has been until now the Municipal Law of 1988 (Ley de Municipios - Ley No. 40). This law authorizes local government to provide services and exercise administrative authority over: (1) environmental protection; (2) regulation of urban development and land use; (3) solid waste management; (4) reforestation; (5) oversight of natural resource use and protection; and (6) creation of mechanisms for popular participation in local decision-making. Several larger and/or better funded municipal governments (e.g., Leon, Chinandega, El Castillo) have begun to exercise these powers through the establishment of municipal environmental offices, employing technical specialists, and creating environmental and natural resource advisory committees. In a number of foreign donor-assisted projects as well, municipal governments are beginning to function in their expanded roles.'4 The 1995 Partial Reform of the Constitution (Reforma Parcial de la Constituci6n) brought important implications for local government. Key aspects of the constitutional reform include: (1) regions were eliminated as administrative units with the exception of the RAAS and RAAN; (2) municipal govermments were given broad responsibilities over socio-economic (rural and urban) development within municipalities; (3) municipal governments must now be consulted regarding natural resource use contracts in their jurisdictions; (4) mayor, vice-mayor and councilors will all be elected directly for a period of four years; and most importantly (5) a percentage of the national budget will be fiscally transferred to those municipalities with lower resource mobilization potential. Following the constitutional reform a new Municipal Law has been drafted that would, inter alia, (1) regulate the election process; (2) more clearly define competencies between municipal and central goverrnments; (3) commit the GON to transfer a percentage of the national public budget to local governments according to pre-established ceilings. IDA has kept an active dialogue with the GON on the decentralization process in the context of the Institutional Development Credit and the preparation activities for the proposed project. IDA has financed technical assistance on decentralization and local public finance issues (see list of reports in project file in Annex 13). 3. The GON recently created the Sectoral Decentralization Commission (SDC -- Comision Sectorial de Descentralizaci6n, 4' Examples of both ongoing and proposed projects include: Brigadas Ecologicas Municipales and PROSDEL (ASDI); PROTMAREN (DANIDA); Modernizaci6n de Sistemas de Producci6n Integral Municipal (EU); Desarrollo Rural Regional Municipal del Norte (GTZ); Fortalacimiento de Capacidad Municipal (JSAID) and; projects financed through the Ministerio de Acci6n Social.

The SDC forms part of the Executive Committee for Public Sector Reform (CERAP -- Comite Ejecutivo para la Reforma de la Administraci6n Ptublica). The SDC is composed of the President of INIFOM, who chairs the SDC, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Education, the President of INAA and the Vice-Minister of the Presidency for State Affairs. The SDC has defined seven overriding principles that should guide the decentralization process: (1) public participation; (2) political conmmitment; (3) gradual change; (4) capacity building and technical assistance; (5) transfer of resources; (6) strong legal framework; and (7) restructuring and modemization of institutions. The proposed IDA project would specifically target aspects (1), (3), (4), (5) and (6). The five immediate tasks of the SDC are to: (1) propose a decentralization strategy; (2) propose the reform to the Municipalities Law including in a system of fiscal transfers for municipalities, to be approved by the National Assembly; (3) strengthen INIFOM; (4) develop a plan of technical assistance and capacity building for municipalities; and (5) implement and test local government models in pilot municipalities. During preparation of the proposed IDA project some of these actions have been supported with preparation funds and would continue to be supported during project implementation. The SDC has already proposed the draft document for the reform to the Municipalities Law (which is an integral part of the decentralization framework) which would define more precisely the constitutional reforms introduced recently. Many of the line agencies (Education, Health, Water, Natural Resources and Environment) are increasingly delegating implementation of programs and projects to the local level. This process is at a critical stage today due to the combination between the weaknesses of local governments, particularly the rural ones, and the demands posed by the decentralization process. Municipal governments are being given an ever increasing role in the economy but for the most part are extremely weak in aspects of planning, administrative and financial management, resource mobilization, delivery of public services, cost recovery, and participatory processes. Thus while there is a new thrust towards decentralization at the national level, rural local institutions are at a loss for assuming their new roles. Capacity strengthening of local governments, including more community participation, which is consistent with the decentralization agenda of GON, must proceed at the same pace as the national decentralization agenda for it to be successful. INIFOM. The key institution in charge of municipal issues at the central government level is the Nicaraguan Institute for Municipal Development (INIFOM; see Chapter 2 of the SAR for a discussion of INIFOM). A recent study supported by IDA's Institutional Development Credit identified the following main weaknesses in INIFOM: (1) unclear role once decentralization is accomplished; (2) high number of managers relative to professional staff, (3) lack of capacity to respond to municipal demands for technical assistance and municipal studies; (4) conflictive roles in municipal development and in municipal auditing and monitoring; (5) employment and career insecurity of INIFOM staff; and (6) weak regional offices. INIFOM has signed an Institutional Restructuring Agreement with CERAP in the Ministry of Finance. Under the IRA, INIFOM agrees to implement the actions defined
 Annex I Background: The Policy and Institutional Context for Decentralization Page 4 of 17 in the Reform of the Public Service under the general supervision of the General Directorate of the Public Service and the financial reforms identified in the Integrated System for Financial Management, Administration and Auditing under the supervision of the Ministry of Finance. More specifically INIFOM agrees to implement the following reforms during the next two years: (1) On Institutional Reform: (a) to define strategic objectives and the institutional role; (b) to redesign the organizational structure; and (c) to establish a system of monitoring and evaluation. (2) On Technical Capacity: (a) to put in place management systems to assist the process of decentralization and municipal governments; (b) to train staff on decentralization and municipal strengthening; and (c) to develop instruments for coordinating donor financed projects. And on Office Technology: to implement a plan for electronic management of databases. Municipal Financing. One critical issue is municipal financing. Among Central American countries, Nicaragua allocates the highest percentage of GDP to municipal financing (3.0% for Nicaragua in 1989 as opposed to 2.4% for Honduras; 1.2% for Guatemala; 1.1% for Costa Rica (1990); and 0.7% for Panama (1987). However in Nicaragua the fourteen more urbanized municipalities capture the lion's share of municipal resources. These fourteen municipalities account for 75% of all municipal expenditures, but include only 49% of the population. While an urban municipality spends on average more than US$20.0 per capita per year the more rural ones invest less than US$0.50 per capita per year. The revenue and expenditure gap between the larger and more urbanized municipalities, usually larger towns where regional offices of central government agencies and most services are concentrated, and smaller and rural ones is due to distortions arising from the municipal financing system. Ninety seven percent of all municipal revenues are generated through various local taxes and fees. There are very limited central government fiscal transfers (3% of total municipality revenues in 1992) and in the absence of fiscal transfers municipalities must rely on programs of line agencies or specialized institutions such as the FISE over which they have little control. In 1992 74% of municipal revenues originated from taxes and fees with the bulk coming from (I) the sales tax (3 7%); (2) the property tax (6%); (3) the vehicle tax (5%); (4) the business registration tax (8%); and (5) user charges and fees (16%). Sales taxes and business registration taxes, in particular, are predominantly collected in trading centers where businesses are located, usually cities and towns. Less urbanized municipalities, which generate important productive activities in agriculture, see these activities be indirectly taxed (namely through the 2 percent sales tax) by urban municipalities but do not share in the revenues. As a result urban municipalities have much larger investment expenditures per capita than rural ones, which do not have the means to invest in the public services necessary for the productive sectors. A background paper prepared in the course of project preparation5 recommends that in the area of municipal financing the GON should: (1) strengthen the finances of municipalities with weak economic bases through a national revenue sharing system; (2) consolidate the current revenue structure of local governments; (3) eliminate 5 See project's background paper in project file: Garz6n, Hernando. 1995. "Municipal Finances and Decentralization".

The draft Municipalities Law in the National Assembly includes a Section on municipal financing proposing a revenue sharing mechanism to compensate municipalities with a low revenue generation potential. The principle is that GON would transfer a percentage of its revenues (4%) to municipalities according to a formula reflecting population, poverty, area, participation effort and own revenue effort. The transfers would be financed by reallocating resources from local development programs currently channeled through INIFOM, National Assembly, MAS and Institute of Sports. Local Governments Project Municipalities During preparation two evaluations of the capacity of the 32 municipalities selected for the project were carried out. The first evaluation developed three typologies of municipality-A, B, and C--according to their revenue resources mobilization capacity (see Table Al. l), while the second evaluation focused on the adequacy of municipal financial management (see Figure A 0. 1). These assessments led to the conclusion that municipal govermnents have important weaknesses, some of them intrinsic to the nature of local govemments, and others resulting from the particular Nicaraguan context: * financial weaknesses that results in part from the limited resources; * administrative weaknesses because of the lack of a professional career at the municipal level which leads to a high tumover of personnel; * urban bias: municipal councils have a vast majority of representatives from urban areas though the share of voters from urban and rural areas is approximately the same in Nicaragua. Although an urban bias is efficient because the cost per beneficiaries of service provision is lower when beneficiaries are concentrated, in Nicaragua this bias is inflated by an electoral process that does not link elected officials to voters in rural areas; * insufficient use of public consultation and participatory approaches; * limited planning capacity, due in part to technical weaknesses, and in part to the lack of resources needed from planning exercises; * difficulties in intemalizing regional, national and global enviromental concems due to the local nature of municipal jurisdictions; * weak legal framework for local public finance and lack of revenue sharing mechanisms that benefit disadvantaged municipalities.

As entities responsible for raising their own operating budgets, municipal governments have had to develop mechanisms for making decisions which include some prioritization and conflict resolution functions. All important decisions are made by the Municipal Council, which has ultimate authority. The strength of the Municipal Councils, however, lies only in their role as a political decision making body, i.e. they are not broadly representative of the municipal population's political or socio-economic diversity. They are elected proportionally from political party lists (which tend to head the lists with candidates from urban areas) with the result that a disproportionate number of councilors are urban residents while rural and urban residents vote in similar proportions. Roughly it was calculated that on average only 13% of councilors reside in rural areas while rural populations contributed roughly 50% of all votes. Hence Municipal Councils do not intemalize as well the concems of rural communities as they do of urban ones and are not well positioned to initiate activities directed at sustainable rural development, rural poverty the environment, and natural resource management. This is further underscored in the majority of project municipalities where the average level of educational attainment among the mayors and councils is low. A special case with a large impact are the Local Development Committees (LDC) created by the Ministry of Social Affairs (MAS). LDCs are local structures made of sometimes elected and sometimes non-elected community representatives and notables (priest, teacher, etc.) that propose local investment priorities for public financing. LDCs are a controversial initiative among municipal governments for two reasons: (1) there has been little financial support for the investments identified by LDCs and thus some people claim that LDCs have lost clout and there is some participation fatigue as the initial efforts led to limited results; and (2) LDCs are a structure that is parallel to and substitutes for decision-making functions of local government (municipal council), hence often are ignored by them.  Annex 1 Background: The Policy and Institutional Context for Decentralization Page 12 of 17 B. Non-Government Organizations (NGOs). Typology of NGOs. Capacity among local NGOs is critical to the feasibility of devolving greater responsibility to the local level (see Table Al.6). NGOs play an extremely imnportant role in most phases of local development and they control substantial human and financial resources.19 NGOs are required to have a legal identity (personalidad jurdica) and under the law are considered as civic, non-profit organizations. Associations and cooperatives (such as for producers) take their legal form and identity through the regulations enforced by the Direcci6n de Cooperativas in the Ministry of Labor. NGOs operating within the project area can be divided into four types: (1) national-level NGOs created before 1990; (2) national-level and local-level NGOs created since 1990; (3) associations with local coverage; and (4) projects administered by foreign donors that convert into NGOs: (1) National-Level NGOs Created Before 1990 includes FUNDE, FACS, CEPAD, CEPRODEL and CAPRI; all of which manage a diverse portfolio of programs that include: social assistance, sustainable development, environment, gender, child care, and emergency response/disaster relief. Since 1990 they have all been implementing credit programs for financing productive activities. Since 1992 they have all also added "green" emphases to their programs. (2) National and Local-Level NGOs Created Since 1990 developed primarily specific thematic areas such as woman-in-development, child care, human rights, sustainable development, environment, etc. Examples of national-level NGOs of this type include: CIPRES which implements sustainable development projects, and NITLAPLAN which specializes in credit intermediation to small and medium farmers. There are numerous examnples of local-level NGOs; as a group they have diverse roots both within the municipalities (e.g. SELVA an environmental NGO which operates only in one municipality) and outside (e.g. Fundaci6n Le6n 2000, an NGO which developed out of a central government agency program). The majority of these NGOs provide services to projects, responding to those areas in which financing is available. (3) Associations With Local Coverage are organizations with a membership consisting of individual farmers or farmer cooperatives. The latter type are second-level associations or cooperative unions (e.g., UNAG, UROCOOM, and UCOOM) whose clients are service and credit cooperatives and multi-sectoral cooperatives. NGO Activities. The activities of the NGOs working within the project area fall within the following categories (see Table Al.6): (1) sustainable development programs - directed toward small farmers in the dry and humid tropics, offering technical options to overcome production constraints (e.g. improved seed, soil and moisture conservation, soil fertility management); (2) micro-enterprise development - primarily credit intermediation programs, these tend to be urban-based programs with little rural presence; (3) credit intermediation - stand alone projects which operate communal banks, cajas rurales, etc. (4) agricultural credit - cooperative programs for production and marketing of basic grains and some few, other agricultural commodities; (5) environmental education - generally oriented toward the promotion of improved farming and land use practices; and (6) women's programs - these tend to focus on micro-activities (e.g. chickens and pigs) at the household-level; there is an incipient trend (e.g. APROAL and UNAG/Chinandega) to recognize women's wider roles in the economy and environment and provide a broader range of opportunities than the current. NGO Capacity. With little exception NGOs are highly dependent on funding from foreign donors; the exceptions are the credit intermediaries and those that sell services (technical assistance, training, marketing). Neither national governrnent nor local philanthropists are a significant source of financing. As a result, the national-level NGOs have had a good deal of experience in proposal writing and competitive fund-raising with foreign donors. The local NGOs have much less experience in these areas, mostly due to a lack of infornation about funding sources and their individual requirements.

They maintain computerized accounting systems and have well-established, professional sources from which to solicit institutional assistance. They are also becoming self-sufficient in terms of recurrent costs, though as yet this does not signify an ability to cover basic administrative costs with their own funds. Having developed the capacity to access multi-lateral funds (e.g., from IDB and EU), they have also had to develop professional systems for project administration and monitoring. As a normal routine, they maintain project funds and the NGO's personal funds in separate bank accounts, keep up-to-date financial and accounting records, and submit themselves to annual external audits. The national NGOs established since 1990 also tend to exhibit a reasonable level of institutional capacity, though less advanced given their shorter institutional life. The majority of the local NGOs created since 1990 demonstrate potential, but as yet their admninistrative capacity is limited. Their weakest area tends to be accounting systems. As noted above, due to the lack of resources for institutional strengthening the development of capabilities in these areas has lagged behind. The exception to this has been those NGOs (e.g. Fundaci6n Le6n 2000) which developed out of central government programs where capacity building funds were provided. The associations with local coverage could be characterized as having a capacity lying somewhere between that of the national and local NGOs. The second-level associations maintain professional accounting and administrative personnel at their central offices. Where the problems occur is at the level of the cooperatives and groups with whom they work. At this level the lack of formal education and resources with which to contract specialized personnel translates into minimal administrative and accounting capabilities. The problems are exacerbated by the absence of any standardized accounting systems and minimal access to training. Where exceptions exist, i.e., in the larger cooperatives that can afford to hire personnel with more education and experience, the lack of resources for training and office equipment (e.g., computers) is an obstacle. As regards the NGOs arising out of foreign donor projects, they are well- trained and professionally equipped, particularly in those cases such as CHINORTE where

Local Technical Capacity for Natural Resources Management On-going Projects. There are a number of initiatives in the project areas directed at improving agricultural productivity. In the Pacific area, there are two important bilaterally financed projects (Proyecto Pikin Guerrero (NORAD) and Proyecto de los Maribios (Netherlands financed, FAO executed)) aimed at developing sustainable agricultural technology in the buffer zone around and on the lower slopes of the Maribios, the chain of volcanos that runs parallel to the coast a little to the north-west of Le6n and Chinandega towns, and a third one (FINNIDA financed) that aims more specifically at reforestation, to establish windbreaks and thus reduce wind erosion. In the Caribbean, there are two main groups working in the field of agricultural technology. One, an NGO "CIPRES" which has substantial experience with soil management (fertility and erosion control) for small farmers and the other, a bi-lateral project (Dutch-financed) "PRODES" which has its own research station and outreach program in Nueva Guinea, where it is developing alternative production systems for the area. Other foreign-financed projects of interest are DANIDAIManglares (developing mangrove management techniques in the Estero Real), and CATIE/MADELENA (applied forestry research and demonstrations for fuelwood, poles and timber production). Technology Transfer. INTA provides rather limited extension services to small and medium-scale farmers, and, in keeping with Government's policy to achieve the gradual privatization of the research and extension agencies, a growing part of these must be provided by the private sector. Presently, INTA fields about 50 technical specialists and 200 extensionists countrywide; in the project area in the Pacific zone there are a total of about 24 extensionists covering 11 municipalities A study no of 88 entities (NGOs, projects, universities, institutions) active in natural resource management found that over 60% of them worked in the promotion of soil conservation and fertility management. The main technical offerings in these areas were live barriers, organic fertilizers, green manure crops, contour cultivation and reforestation. Only 21% of these worked directly with agricultural production, though this primarily implied improved seed and provision of hand tools. Other activities (e.g., family gardens, IPM, forest and fruit tree nurseries and small irrigation) were promoted by 13% of the entities studied. Only 4% assisted with commercialization of farm products. One of the main weaknesses identified by the study was the lack of training for technical personnel; the overwhelming majority of resources for training were directed toward farmers and fanner/technicians. The number of natural resource technical specialists and professionals (agronomists, agriculturalists, livestock specialists, foresters, biologists, botanists, ecologists etc) in the project areas (Pacific and Caribbean zones) is uncertain.  NICARAGUA RURAL MUNICIPALITIES PROJECT ANNEX 2 BACKGROUND: NATURAL RESOURCES ISSUES AND THE PROJECT AREA!' 1. NATURAL RESOURCES ISSUES Nicaragua is a country known both for its large areas of still pristine forests, watercourses and coral reefs in the Atlantic and for a high level of resource degradation in the Pacific, Northem and Central regions. Underlying most of the resource degradation are misguided policies, extreme poverty, the civil war and migratory pressures due to the war and other factors. The Atlantic region has so far escaped these pressures due to poor access, low population density and the war period during which various armed groups sought refuge in its forests. The situation is changing however and pressure from refugees, landless farmers and legitimate development needs are accelerating the advance of the agricultural frontier. Soils While soil erosion is considered to be the most important cause of soil degradation on a national level, other phenomena may be as or more important on a local scale (i.e. compactation, salinization, acidification, and sodification). Erosion by water is the main process of interest, wind erosion is also important in numerous (specific) locations throughout the westem half of the country. About 7.7 million ha are affected by erosion, of which 52% is classified as having light to moderate erosion; 33% as having moderate to high erosion; and 15% as high to severe erosion. The main causes of accelerated erosion are: (1) deforestation; (2) lack of integration of conservation practices into land use practices (including roads); (3) rapid, uncontrolled expansion of annual cropping and livestock over the last 30 years; and (4) inappropriate land uses. At a national level, drops in yield have been noted and ascribed to erosion. Little empirical evidence exists though one study found a yield decline in com of 82% over a 9 year period as a result of soil loss (NEAP/NIC, 1994). Areas identified as having priority erosion/soil degradation problems are: (1) the southern watershed of Managua; (2) the foothills of the San Cristobal, Chonco and Casita volcanic complex; (3) the foothills of Volcan Cosiguina; (4) Le6n - La Paz Centro areas; (5) south slope of the Meseta de Carazo; (6) Volcan Mombacho and adjacent areas; (7) the plains in the Tipitapa - Granada area; (8) the northwestern portion of the Rio Coco watershed; (9) the Jalapa Valley; and (10) the Nueva Guinea area. Forests Since 1950 forest cover has been reduced from 7 million hectares to an estimated 4.3 million hectares (TFAP, 1992). Other authors estimates range from between 0.07 million ha/yr in 1990 (Utting, 1993) to about 0.125 million ha/yr for the period 1981 to 1990 (FAO, 1993) and 1991 (Merlet et al, 1993). According to the NEAP (1994) this rate has increased in the last few years to 0.15 million ha/yr. Land classified as suitable only for forestry usage occupies about 6.2 million ha; divided as 1.8 million ha for conservation and 4.4 million ha for sustainable use. Some 2.5 million hectares of these lands are deforested and being used for extensive livestock production or are abandoned and under mixed grass/shrubs. Of the remaining forest areas about 88% or 3.8 million hectares consists of a humid, tropical forest cover type with which there is very little positive management experience to draw upon. The main value of forests in Nicaragua has been in its conversion to agriculture. As such, the "expansion of the agricultural frontier" is reported to be the principle cause of deforestation. The greatest pressures are apparently in the Atlantic and parts of the Central zone. At current rates it is estimated that only 10 to 15 years would be required to eliminate the remaining areas of productive broadleaf forests (NEAP, 1994). The end of the war and return of peace to the near-forest zones and demobilization of a large number of soldiers (both government and contras) in recent years has apparently contributed significantly to an increase in the rate of conversion. The expansion of agricultural lands and forest conversion also have roots which lie in: (1) lack of economic incentives for forest management; (2) low productivity and non-sustainable agricultural practices; (3) poorly defined or missing land tenure; (4) lack of alternate employment; (5) a strong agricultural tradition in which forests are considered an obstacle; and (6) little or no tradition of forest management. The traditional system for forest management in Nicaragua has been to remove only the valuable species with no subsequent consideration of damage to the residual stand or for follow up management and/or control. In this system forest was not treated as a renewable resource, it was simply mined for its value. There are very few examples in the country of forest management for long term production. In addition, information to manage the forests is generally lacking. The forests and lands which belong to the state have never been defined or delimited. National and regional trend data on forest cover and forest use is lacking. Management data on forest resource abundance, distribution and regenerative capacity is almost completely missing. In 1992 about 60% of net energy consumption came from fuelwood (57%) and charcoal (1 %); almost 99% of which went for residential use (NEAP/NIC, 1994). According to the TFAP (1992), wood fuel represented about 95% of the average US$ 148.8 million annual value of forestry products in the early 1990s. Whether or not fuelwood harvesting constitutes a forest degrading activity in some locations is unknown. What is certain is that fuelwood production and harvesting is unmanaged and risks exist of it becoming a forest degrading activity. Harvesting and sales of wood fuels constitutes a significant income generating activity among the rural poor. Fuelwood is in short supply near densely populated urban centers and prices have been reported as being high. However, near densely populated areas in the Pacific zone (i.e. Le6n) there are indications that fuelwood is currently priced as if it were abundant. Given the large areas of land being allowed to reconvert to woody vegetation, fuelwood may indeed be abundant.
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 3 of 12 Fire is apparently a problem in a large number of areas where recurrent burning (primarily for agricultural purposes) is a major contributor to forest degradation and failure of reforestation efforts. Water Inappropriate land uses, lack of a regulatory framework and inadequate protection (e.g. effluent and solid waste treatment, control of contaminants, provision and enforcement of penalties/incentives, etc) have all contributed to a deterioration of the nation's water resources. Problems are further intensified by a lack of planming and subsequent conflicts over water allocation (e.g. between hydroelectric and irrigation). Specific, priority issues include scarcity, watershed management and water quality. Scarcity. The Pacific side and Central Zones receive the least rainfall and commonly, both their rural and urban areas are characterized as suffering water supply deficits. Conflict over water allocation appear certain to increase given the desire to expand irrigated areas and divert water for economic development (e.g. agroprocessing facilities). Drought in some degree is not infrequent in many parts of the Pacific and Central zones and the current farming systems, particularly of the small farmers appear to be extremely vulnerable to drought. Land use practices which decrease the infiltration of rainfall (e.g. frequent burning, up-and-down slope cultivation, etc) may be contributing to reductions in groundwater and of surface water low flows on some local scale. Other factors contributing to the deficits undoubtedly include population increases with little or no parallel investment in upgrading of water systems and in some areas of the Pacific zone possibly includes uncontrolled exploitation of groundwater. Watershed management. Watersheds which have been identified as requiring management for production of surface water include: Managua - Rio Mico; Matagalpa - Rios San Francisco and Molino Norte; San Rafael del Sur - Rio Jesus; Nueva Guinea - Rio Zapote; Ocotal - Rio Dipilto; Boaco - Rio Fonseca; and Puerto Cabezas - Rios Taupi and Braquiria. Those identified as requiring management for groundwater include: Chinandega - Rio Acome; Santo Tomas - Rio Cuipar; and Bluefields - Rio Escofran. Potable water. About 20% of the rural population versus 79% of the urban population have access to potable water (NEAP, 1994). In comparative terns, the percentage of persons with access to potable water in Nicaragua is the lowest in Central America. Over 80% of rural households suffer from contaminated water (World Bank, 1992. SAR Social Investment Fund) Water quality. There are no systematic data regarding water quality therefore a comprehensive overview of the problems cannot be given. What is known about the dimensions of water quality consists of: (1) Lake Managua. The lake comprises the worst case of contamination in the country. Apart from the natural salinization process which the lake is undergoing, other causes of diminishing water quality include: the direct discharge of sewage, industrial wastes, agrochemicals (both from use and
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 4 of 12 manufacture), effluents from the Momotombo Geothermal Plant, garbage dumping on the lakeshores and sediment inflows. It is estimated that over 40 tons of mercury have been discharged into the lake in the last 20 years. Other lakes reportedly suffering from serious contamination include the Lagunas Tiscapa and Masaya. Water quality of Lake Managua is being handled through an IDB project currently under preparation. (2) Industrial contamination. One of the potentially most serious problems in the country is associated with Laguna Asososca, which is an important water supply for Managua. Apparently the laguna receives water from the aquifer which lies below the industrial zone between Laguna Asososca and Lake Managua. The aquifer has been contarninated by industrial discharges thus affecting water quality in the laguna. Relatively good data exists on the physico-chemical and bacteriological status of the laguna. (3) Agrochemical contamination. The high rates of pesticide usage in some agricultural areas, especially the (current and past) cotton growing areas, has resulted in agrochemical residues in both groundwater and surface water. In the Pacific zone around Chinandega, El Viejo, El Realejo y Le6n levels of nitrate nitrogen in groundwater exceed 40 mg/It (or 4 times the amount allowed in the United States). In the Pacific and Central zones, the agrochemical contamination of surface water is reported for the rivers Esteli, Grande de Matalgalpa, Jinotega-Apanas, Acome, Chiquito, Oro, Fonseca, Mayales and San Juan. The Jinotega and Matagalpa rivers, in addition, receive significant levels of direct discharges from coffee processing. (4) Sediment. Accelerated erosion caused by inappropriate land use practices is reported in all parts of the country. No empirical data is available. Impacts are reported in all estuaries, lakes and river courses. Sediments would be a major vehicle for transport of agro-chemicals to water bodies. (5) Urban Areas. Fecal contamination, non-point source pollution from agriculture, industrial effluents and deficiencies in the wastewater systems are the main problems. Managua, among all urban areas, has the greatest problems. (6) Mining. The rivers Tunky (or Sucio), Mico, Maiz and Tecomapa are reported to be contaminated by cyanide and other heavy metals as a result of mining and processing activities. (7) Saltwater intrusion. Overexploitation of groundwater in some of the westem parts of the country (e.g. Chichigalpa, Chinandega, Corinto, and Poneloya) has caused saltwater intrusion as far as I Okm inland from the coast.
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 5 of 12 Coastal Zone and Fisheries In Nicaragua three of Central America's five largest rivers feed a unique system of bays and lagoons which serve as critical breeding habitat for major commercial species (e.g. shrimp and lobster). On the Pacific side, sedimentation and agrochemical residues (e.g. in Estero Real in the Gulf of Fonseca) are potentially effecting the wild shrimp populations which breed in these waters. On the Caribbean side rich coral and sea grass resources (one of the largest sea grass areas in the world) exist which are habitat for the endangered manatee and almost one-half of the Atlantic's population. The commercial and biodiversity values of these areas are perhaps the highest in Central America. Priority issues include the fishery, shrimp culture and mangroves: Fishery. Fishing pressures are known to be increasing while adequate data is not available either on the magnitude of the catch nor on the carrying capacity of the resource. The fishery is little diversified and thus the majority of fishing efforts are concentrated on a few species (sea bass, lobster, green sea turtle, shark and red snapper). There is some indication that the shrimp catch along the Pacific coast and the lobster catch along the Caribbean have reached their limits. In addition, the unregulated use of fish traps and the high loss of non-target species caused by shrimper's nets are thought to be significant factors contributing to the observed declines in marine fauna populations. Shrimp culture. The expansion of shrimp culture is thought to have little scientific base and to potentially be destroying coastal habitat with unknown effects on zones which are extremely important as breeding grounds for both marine and avifauna. It is feared that uncontrolled expansion of shrimp culture will begin along the Caribbean coast in those areas which are critical breeding habitat for six commercial species of (wild) shrimp. Mangroves. The main area of mangrove loss is along the Pacific coast. The losses are the results of: (a) harvesting fuelwood and timber for local use; and (b) shrimp culture, both from clearing and ponds creating changes in water levels and salinity. Biodiversity Less is known about the biodiversity values of Nicaragua than any other Central American country. Ten principal ecosystems have been identified and described; the identification work, however, is not necessarily complete. Information on biota is highly uneven. Some 1,200 species or an estimated 95% of vertebrates have been identified, whereas an estimated 65% of plant species have been identified (8,550 species with 56 endemic species). The list of saltwater fish (311 Pacific species and 305 Atlantic species), mollusks (2,000 species), corals (42 species), and plants (107 algae species and 5 sea grasses) and of freshwater fish (46 species with II endemic) is considered to be almost complete. The lists of terrestrial invertebrates is extremely weak and the only insect and mycological information available is on those with economic importance to the agricultural sector. Specific, priority issues include loss of biodiversity, habitat loss and protected areas. Loss of biodiversity. The primary causes of species and ecosystem loss are the same as those driving deforestation with the addition of conmmercial harvesting pressures to
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 6 of 12 supply a growing local and intemational market with specimens and products from wildlife. It is estimated that 2% of terrestrial vertebrates are in danger of extinction and 10% are currently threatened. The agricultural frontiers to the north and east are the most dynamic zones of loss. Habitat loss. The overwhelming majority of tropical dry forest habitat has already been lost as these areas were the initial zones cleared for livestock and some annual crop cultivation. Only remnants of this forest type still exist within the Pacific zone. Little information is available on mangrove habitat and trends in loss. Pressure on mangrove may be increasing in the westem coastal zone areas near the Honduran border where development of shrimp culture is of interest (Coastal resources). Protected areas. Within the approximately 3.4 million hectares of land which have undergone little modification from human influences there are about 2 million hectares which are considered in the NEAP to be worthy of protection within the protected areas system. To date over 85% of this 2 million hectares lies within 71 legally constituted protected areas; legally constituted by presidential decrees, not by a protected areas system law. Among these 71 areas are: a) 0.06 million hectares under active protection and/or management; b) 0.25 million hectares under some minimal protection scheme; and iii) the remainder without management plans, without management activities of any kind, and without any personnel to guard or monitor the area. The other 1.4 million hectares are classified as production forest or potential agricultural lands. Under the General Environrnent Law of 1996 new protected areas will need to be approved by law. 2. LEGISLATION, STRATEGIES AND INSTITUTIONS Legal Framework The national environmental action plan (neap) notes that the laws and policies governing ownership and use of natural resources are out-dated, disjointed and incoherent. The most critical need is passage of legislation and/or regulations covering eleven natural resources and related themes: environment, forestry, mining, fisheries, biodiversity, protected areas, pollution, water, soil conservation, coastal zone management, indigenous land and natural resources issues, and municipal and autonomous governments. Nicaragua has made important efforts to rationalize the legal framework for natural resources; the general environment law was ratified by the national assembly in April 1996. Various laws are in draft form or already under discussion in the national assembly (the fisheries law, the mining law, the energy law and the pollution law). Natural Resources Strategies In spite of the legislative bottlenecks noted above, some progress has been made recently in developing a national strategy for the environment and natural resources: Presidential Decree 246-92 approved (1) the National Forestry Action Plan (TFAP); (2) the National Strategy for Conservation and Sustainable Development (ECODESNIC); (3) the Strategy for Environment and Land Use Planning (EOAT). The National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) was approved by Presidential Decree 261-93 on December 3, 1993.

Rio San Juan Natural Resources Institutions Rural Development. The National Agricultural Council (CONAGRO) was created in 1993 by presidential decree to coordinate policies and activities between the Ministry of Agriculture, the Institute of Natural Resources (IRENA, now MARENA), and the Institutes of Agrarian Reforn and Agricultural Technology (INRA and INTA). Since 1994 CONAGRO has grown in importance, having assumed the role of key coordinating GON structure for rural development and has placed high on its agenda issues relating to the
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 8 of 12 management of natural resources. INRA (Instituto Nicaraguense de Reforma Agraria) is the institution in charge of titling lands. It is being supported by the IDA's Agricultural Technology and Land Titling and Land Management Project (Credit No.2536-NI) and plans during the project to award about 25,000 titles in the Pacific, Northern and Central regions. INTA (Instatuto Nicaraguense de Tecnologia Agropecuaria) is the institution in charge of research and extension. It is also being supported by IDA Credit No. The PNDR (Programa Nacional de Desarollo Rural) was recently created as a result of an IDB project of the same name. The focus of the PNDR was initially on the Central region of Nicaragua, but since then it has absorbed various donor financed rural development projects that were spread out through several institutions, namely MAG and MARENA. MAG has seen its role weakened following the proliferation of specialized institutes and programs. A draft Law on the Organization, Competencies and Procedures of the Executive Branch of Government (Proyecto de Ley de Organizaci6n, Competencias y Procedimientos del Poder Ejecutivo) is being discussed in the National Assembly. In this law the proposed mission of the MAG would be (1) to manage the agriculture development policy; (2) to promote crop diversification; (3) to develop agriculture crop zoning; (4) to cooperate in plans and programs for environmental protection; (5) to establish agricultural schools; (6) to promote the competitiveness of agricultural production; (6) to collaborate in industrialization and commercialization of agricultural products; and (7) to manage fitosanitary controls. Natural Resources and Environment. In January 1994, a new Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MARENA) was created out of the former IRENA by Presidential Decree 1-94. It now has the authority to: (1) coordinate and direct all public policy towards natural resources; (2) promote sustainable use of natural resources; and (3) to propose laws, regulations, standards and strategies for sustainable use and protection of natural resources and the environment through participatory processes. Currently, MARENA is, together with INIFOM, one of the first six institutions of Government participating in the reestructuring contemplated in the Institutional Development Credit. This credit would support the streamlining of MARENA and the strengthening of its basic functions including financial management, functional structure and personnel and administration. Recommendations already under implementation include the reorganization of the Ministry into three inter- disciplinary directorates (Policy and Strategy, Regulation and Control, and Interinstitutional Relations) and the devolution of some natural resource projects to the PNDR and municipalities, along with appropriate technical assistance to strengthen municipal capacity. The main activities to be financed by the Institutional Development Credit are the following: (1) institutional reorganization including redefinition of mission, objectives, functions, organization and administrative procedures; (2) implementing a system for coordinating externally financed projects; (3) improvement of project management; and (4) develop and implement a strategy for information technology. In 1996 a new General Environment Law created the National Environment Comnuission, headed by MARENA, in charge of coordinating environmental activities and an Environment Fund, to channel resources for the environment. Enforcement Agencies. The General Environment Law of 1996 created an Office of Environmental Affairs in the General Attomey's Office. Additionally, prior to this legal development which has not yet materialized with the necessary appointments and funding the Armed Forces and the National Police have been assuming an increasing role in matters of
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 9 of 12 environmental and natural resources legislation. The Armed Forces includes in its statutes (C6digo de Organizaci6n, Jurisdiccion y Previsi6n Social Militar; Ley 181 de 02.09.94) supporting the branches of the executive with natural resource conservation and renovation, improving the environment and ecological equilibrium and collaborating in the strategic plans established by the President, which include the Tropical Forestry Action Plan and the National Environmental Action Plan. In March 1995 MARENA and the Armed Forces signed an interinstitutional agreement (Convenci6n Interinstitucionalpara la Conservac6n delMedio Ambiente y Uso Sostenible de los Recursos Naturales MARENA-EPS, 29 de Marzo de 1995) which defines the areas and mechanisms of coordination between the two institutions. Under this agreement the Armed Forces agreed to include in its annual operating plans activities ranging from monitoring of protected areas to the control of illegal trade of wildlife. The National Police executes orders issued by the authorities and in particular by MARENA in the natural resources and environmental areas. The National Police has signed a special agreement with the Ministry of Health through which the police assumed the role of sanitary inspectors. A similar agreement for the control of illegal logging is being discussed with MARENA. Neither the Armed Forces nor the National Police have any special training on natural resources and environmental aspects and this is considered a major constraint that prevents these institutions from assuming the roles contained in the agreements they subscribed to. Other Environmental Institutions. A number of other institutions intervene in the natural resources and environmental areas. The Ministry of Health has responsibilities over water contamination. INAA (Instituto Nicaraguense de Acuaductos y Alcantarrillados) regulates water use, proposes the establishment of water reserves in collaboration with MARENA and cooperates with the Ministry of Health on water pollution. The National Commission of Hydrological Resources (Comisi6n Nacional de Recursos Hidricos), which depends from the President of the Republic, is in charge of water policy and solving water use conflicts. The Ministry of Construction and Transport, together with MARENA, has responsibilities over oil and other fossil fuels pollution. The National Ports Corporation (Empresa Nacional de Puertos) and the General Directorate of Aquatic Transportation (Direcci6n General de Transporte Acudtico), together with MARENA, oversee contamination by ships. The Ministry of Agriculture and MARENA oversee issues of soil conservation. The Ministry of Agriculture, MARENA, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Construction and Transport, Ministry of Labor, Ministry of Finance (Customs) and the municipalities all have responsibilities over agro-chemical contamination, a very serious problem in Nicaragua, in particular in the cotton rich area of Le6n and Chinandega. Until recently Nicaragua was the largest producer of DDT in Central America and although DDT is now banned, problems of contamination by this and other substances persist and are considered a serious health hazard and one of the most critical environmental issues in the country. The Ministry of Economy is in charge of issuing licenses and concessions for the fishery, mining and forestry, but MARENA has a control and monitoring role over both the fishery resource and forests and contamination from mining. The Nicaraguan Fisheries Corporation is in charge of fisheries policy. 3. NATURAL RESOURCES ISSUES IN THE PROJECT AREA Some 1.7 million of Nicaragua's 4.2 million people live in rural areas. Among these rural inhabitants, 55% live in poverty and another 20% live in extreme poverty (IDA
 Annex 2 Background: Natural Resources Issues and the Project Area Page 10 of 12 Poverty Assessment, 1993). For rural people, the natural resources sector (including agriculture) provides the main opportunities for income generation and employment. Currently agriculture provides about 90% of employment for an estimated 420,000 persons. Relative to other economic sectors, the agricultural sector has the lowest individual income and wages. Agricultural employment is highly correlated with poverty. Despite limited economic opportunities, the number of persons seeking a livelihood from natural resources based sectors (including agriculture) has increased. With unemployment at 13% nationally and underemployment estimated at 44%, the natural resources based sectors serve as the "employer of last resort"; they are a social safety net where the exploitation of natural capital subsidizes the survival of the poor and unemployed. The combination of rural poverty and lack of altemative employment is expressed on the environment through: (1) increasing soil degradation from deforestation ' followed by the conversion of forest lands to marginal livestock and agricultural uses and from the lack of integration of conservation practices into land uses; (2) increasing degradation of forest and biodiversity resources due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier, non-application of control and management systems in all types of exploitations (fuelwood, poles, timber, hunting, harvesting of secondary products, etc), and inadequate protection of parks and reserves; (3) ongoing deterioration of water resources due to watershed degradation, sediment loading, lack of treatment of effluent (urban, agroprocessing, mining), and over-pumping of groundwater; and (4) over-fishing and destruction of mangroves for domestic purposes and shrimp pond construction. Two regions where this situation is of particular concern are: (1) the former cotton production areas of the Pacific (Departments of Le6n and Chinandega) where the decline of cotton production has eliminated the region's major employer and forced many ex-agricultural laborers and their children to turn to subsistence farming seeking land in areas of fragile natural resources or to migrate to cities; and (2) along the agricultural frontier in the Atlantic in the Departments of Rio San Juan, Chontales and Jinotega and in RAAS and RAAN. In the latter, many ex-combatants and displaced persons have moved to the agricultural frontier in search of lands and livelihood. A significant percentage of the poorest households are female headed. Many of the rural householders are "new" farmers having had little or no previous life experience as agriculturalists. Also in the Atlantic, climatic and soil conditions are sufficiently different from those in Nicaragua's other agricultural regions that even experienced farmers coming there are at a disadvantage. 2 _ In the Pacific zone much of the deforestation is historic, however there is yet ongoing degradation of the remnant forest areas for domestic uses (timbers, poles, fuelwood). As the remaining Pacific forests are generally those found in protected areas, upper watersheds, and coastal zones (mangroves), the value of the environmental services which they perform as wildlife and breeding habitat and watershed protection are still significant both locally and internationally (i.e. Golfo de Fonseca and the forests of the Cordillera Volcanica Central).

SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONDITIONS OF THE PROJECT AREA Project Stakeholders The primary stakeholders of the project are: (l) small farmers and other rural poor-both men and women; (2) other farmers; (3) children and youth; (4) commnunity based organizations; (5) the Subtiaba indigenous group; (6) NGQs; (7) municipal governments; and (8) central government agencies. With the exception of some central government agencies it is expected that all stakeholders will gain from the project. Some central government agencies, in particular in the rural sector, could oppose the project since decentralization would somewhat reduce their power. General Economic and Demographic Features The agricultural land in Leon and Chinandega used to be the most fertile of the country-both areas were major producers of corn, beans and fruits. Since the 1950s, however, production shifted towards export commodities like cotton, sugar cane and bananas. The shift in production caused a loss of soil fertility over the long-In due to inappropriate technzologies and over reliance on agrochemicals. The civil war, political conflict, returning refugees, decreasing export crop prices, inflation and environrnental degradation have since contributed to produce a decline in the living standards of the population. With a

RURAL POVERTY Living Conditions of the Poor LSMS respondents in rural areas of the Westem region and SA participants were distributed among 31 rural communities. The conditions of the 31 conmmunities are as follows: * 2 have post offices * 8 have paved roads leading to their communities * 13 do not have access to motorized transportation * 8 have a doctor and 6 a nurse, 13 do not have any doctor, nurse or midwife * 4 have a pharmacy * 5 do not have primary schools * none of the commnunities have a daily market. All respondents agreed that living conditions had not improved during the five years previous to 1993. On the contrary, members of 26 communities believed that conditions had worsened while the other five believed they have stayed the same. Absence of employment opportunities, inflation, and high cost of living are the reasons given for this situation. In Puerto Morazan it was reported during the RRA that "we are poorer now than before because there are no sources of employment'" Very often, the pessimism is expressed in a 5 The Government is receiving support for land titling through IDA's Agricultural Technology and Land Management Project.

Access to water and sanitation in the project area is inadequate, particularly among the rural poor. Less than half all households in the Westem Region have piped in-house water, of which 72 percent of non-poor and 7 percent are extremely poor. Urban residents have greater access to piped water but differences between poor and non-poor are greater in these urban zones. Seventy percent of urban households have piped water, of which almost four fifths are non-poor and 3 percent are poor. The inequality between groups is less dramatic in rural areas because so few have access to water: 70 percent of the extreme poor, 63 percent of the poor, and 68 percent of the non-poor do not have in-house piped water in rural zones. Access to sanitation services is even scarcer. Only about 20 percent of all households in the Western region are connected to public sewer systems, most of them non-poor households. The extreme poor simply do not have access to sanitation services. Even septic tanks benefit only 7 percent of households. In rural areas of the Western Region, 99 percent of households have no access to public sewer systems, septic tanks, or cesspools. All households with access to any of these types of sanitation services are non-poor. The Poor's Perceptions of the Causes of Poverty According to the local rural population, three major factors cause poverty: lack of employment, diminishing productivity and limited markets. Participants cited stagnant agricultural and livestock activities as the main reasons for limited employment and income. For those who own the land, productivity has diminished and there is no credit available. Among landowners interviewed during the RRA, 83 percent had not received credit or financial assistance during the year prior to the interview. Lack of extemal and internal markets emerged as another primary reasons for poverty. As explained by a small farner in El Viejo, "The peasants do not have seeds, do not have minimal agricultural inputs, there is no credit, there is no one to whom to sell, someone who buys instead of robbing us." Data from the LSMS confirm the people's evaluation of their own poverty. Altogether, 56 percent of respondents reported not working in the seven days prior to the date of the interview, and 51 percent reported not having looked for a job, which can be interpreted as an indicator of hopelessness. Once again, differences between urban and rural areas are striking. Of those who had worked, 60 percent were urban-based and 40 percent were from rural areas. During the year prior to the LSMS, 50 percent reported not having worked and of those who had worked, 81 percent were urban residents. Among those rural inhabitants who consider themselves employed, 41 percent are self-employed. Irrational natural resources management is not cited in the RRA as a cause of poverty and low agricultural productivity. Although there is a broad recognition that this is a constraint, environment degradation was overwhelmingly identified as a consequence of poverty as opposed to a cause. Male temporary migration is now a common feature of the region. Migration is directed towards Costa Rica more often than to other rural areas of Nicaragua. According to a

GENDER ISSUES Gender Roles and Priorities While men's roles in the economy are well acknowledged, women play an important role in the survival strategies of the poor not only through their partnership with men in conjugal-headed households, but because they frequently live on their own, heading households without a male partner. Studies in Nicaragua indicate that while rural men control productive resources and land, women in poor households-both jointly and single headed-contribute significantly to household income. Single headed female households depend exclusively on women's income. Similarly, women in conjugal households are often responsible for providing fbr the family during the agricultural off-season and periods of scarcity. Particularly when fann and off-fhrm opportunities for men are restricted, women will resort to selling garden products and small livestock, petty trading and domestic labor in order to sustain the family. Women's crops are also a major source of family nutrients year round and therefore represent a key element of the rural poor's survival strategies. The survey showed that in terms of addressing poverty, support to agricultural production is the highest priority of men and women, however, their agricultural technology, extension and training needs will vary. A division of labor in agricultural and livestock production exists in Nicaragua. Broadly speaking, basic grains and livestock are primarily the domain of men while women are the dominant producers of horticulture products, fruits and small livestock and play a secondary role in producing basic grains. Women also predominate in marketing farm products. Men and women use natural resources for different purposes and this, in tum, affects their priorities and participation levels in environmental projects. The principal causes of deforestation in the project area are felling for commnercial purposes, the expansion of agricultural lands and hunting-which are typically male activities and hence male interests. Women, in contrast, tend to be more concerned about domestic fuelwood. Water emerged as a prirnary interest of both men and women but while domestic consumption was a female concem, men showed greater interest in water for irrigation and production. Gender-based interests in natural resources are reflected in participation rates in environmental projects which tend to have intrinsic social goals and be domninated by women. Women's decision- making roles on these projects, however, is usually less prominent than men's. Gender Differences in Education Female single-headed households are at disadvantage when it comes to education. Education plays a central role in an individual's ability to move out of poverty and, therefore, the fact that female heads of households are much less educated than males places female single-headed households in a more vulnerable position. The gender inequality pattem is pervasive in the Western region in which, for each educational level complete, male heads outnumber women heads on a 2 to I basis up to the primary level and on a 4 to 1 basis from the secondary level as graph 4 in the next page shows. The pattem of inequality is greater in rural than in urban areas.
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Westem Region Page 11 of 22 Gender and Participation in Rural Organizations The SA indicates that men and women are involved in different forms of organization with women participating to the greatest extent in service-oriented groups (religious and community) and men predominating in producer organizations (UNAG, cooperatives and unions). For example, men comprise 88 percent of members of agriculture and livestock cooperatives in the region. Men also predominate in municipal governmen. in the region, comprising 83 percent of mayors and 89 percent of the consejales. While a gender breakdown of local government committees (comarcales) is not available, it is expected that women's and men's involvement is more balanced given that these committees typically consist of the local midwife, teacher and health worker as well as representatives of producer groups and the church.
