 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Westem Region Page 12 of 22 5. THE SUTIABAS Who Are the Sutiabas? The Sutiabas are one of thirteen Nicaraguan indigenous groups that claim a "native background". In the words of a Sutiabas leader, "nativ background is the right that all of us, native people, have, to respect our own culture and historical lraditions,fornm of social organization and the ownership of our communal land". The basis for the Sutiabas ethnic identity is rooted in their kinship relationships, which provide social and ethnic cohesion. The Sutiabas kinship system, however, has been eroded as a result of the changes that the country has experienced through its history. Kinship is no longer restricted to the children of Sutiaba fathers and mothers, but rather to the identification of individuals with Sutiabas values and costumes. The migration of ladinos to the Sutiaba region, attracted by the possibility of fanning communal lands since colonial times, allowed for a reinterpretation of kinship networks to include the children of the ethnic nix which resulted from migration. Migration also brought about acculturation, loss of control over communal land property, and periods of violence resulting discrimination and from the predominance of ladinos. Sutiaba History Since Spanish colonization, the history of the Sutiabas is characterized by a permanent tension on land rights and efforts on the part of Le6n landowners to take increasingly larger tracts of traditional indigenous territories. Strategies to squeeze the Sutiaba's traditional land rights included invading their lands, dissolving Sutiaba autonomous forms of economic and social organization through national government legislation and promoting "ladinizacion" of indigenous communities. Since the mid-18th Century, the Sutiabas have constituted an independent political-administrative division of the city of Le6n. In 1850, with the introduction of coffee plantations, the need for labor led the government to issue legislation on vagrancy and mandatory labor which justified the forceful and massive recruitment of Indians for farm labor. The introduction of cotton crops in the 1950s exacerbated tensions and violence. Some battles have marked the Sutiabas political conscience and have became political references which, in tum, have strengthened their ethnic identity. Intemal contradictions on the most effective means of conducting such disputes, on the other hand, have weakened the community to some extent. Sutiabas Demographics The Sutiaba population of about 36,000 constitutes 17 percent of the total population in the Department of Le6n.6 The majority -approximately 23,000-live in urban areas and the remaining 12,000 living in rural areas. Rural Sutiabas are spread over nine rural comarcas which are also populated by non-Sutiaba residents. Rural residents currently occupy an area of approximately 580 square kilometers, which represents a small fraction of previous Sutiabas' territory. ' Census Population Projections, Ministry of Health, 1995.
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Western Region Page 13 of 22 Urban Sutiaba live in the traditional historical site of the Sutiaba pueblo, on the westem side of the city of Leo6n and in twenty-four small urban settlements to the North, South and West of the Sutiaba pueblo. The Governuent created these settlements in the mid-80s as part of its overall strategy to counter military aggression originating in neighboring Honduras. The municipal administration of Le6n, has been using the areas around the Sutiaba community to establish settlements and absorb the city's natural urban growth. Such settlements -although created without consulting the Sutiabas-are not a source of conflict because the Sutiaba community has accepted the new settlers. Overall, it is estimated that around 15 percent of the urban population (approximately 3,500 residents) live in the settlements, with the remainder living in the historical Sutiaba site. Although the majority of residents have local Sutiaba ancestry, it common for all dwellers in Sutiaba territory to identify themselves as indigenous Sutiabas, to share the Sutiabas cultural traditions, and to make claims to communal land. Ninety-eight of RRA participants identified themselves as indigenous Sutiaba, although only 71 percent have either the father or the mother born in Sutiaba. The same percentage of women and men identified themselves as indigenous Sutiabas, although there are more women (80 percent) than men (64 percent) with at least one Sutiaba parent. The Sutiabas Land Claims Presently, Sutiaba lands extend from the Northwest to the Southeast of the City of Le6n, in the plains between the Maribios Mountains and the Pacific coast. The land is mostly flat except south of the city of Le6n where slopes are steeper and elevations reach almost 150 meters above sea level. Two rivers, the Telica and the Chiquito cut the region. The Chiquito River has been contaminated by domestic and industrial waste. Both rivers contain about 40 percent of all river water in the department. Statistical data on Sutiaba land and land ownership is conflicting and disorganized. Different versions of what constitutes Sutiaba property makes it difficult to deternine precisely which portion of the land belongs to the conmmunity, which portion belongs to peasants and which portions were under the control of other groups. The royal title in the hands of the indigenous community states that the land belonging to the Sutiabas is equal to 63 "caoallerias" and 12 "atillos", ancient Spanish measures about which there is no information on the corresponding area. A key to understanding the Sutiabas land situation is the way land titles have been distributed and are recognized. Within the 7,000 hectares which are under the direct control of the conmmunity, many small farmners were given supplementary titles to land.. Only 11 percent of small farmers recognze that the land they work is part of traditional communal lands. Fewer than 15 percent of members of local cooperatives are Sutiabas, but these cooperatives own between 27 and 30 percent of traditional Sutiaba lands (8,000 hectares). Among rural and urban participants of the RRA, about 44 percent do not own any property, 45 percent own some property, and the rest work on communal properties. Fifty percent of land owners own less than 10 manzanas and the vast majority-89 percent-have registered legal title to the property. Only 3 percent of Sutiabas farmers were cooperative
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Westem Region Page 14 of 22 menbers. Eighty percent of urban Sutiabas do not own land and 6 percent are small landowners with properties less than 3 manzanas. The majority of Sutiabas live in poverty, have few resources for market production and are exposed to climatic hazards. Farmers with properties of about 15 hectares who live above the poverty line constitute only 8 percent of farmers. In rural areas, only 6 percent of residents do not own any land but about 50 percent own properties smaller than 3.5 hectares and live in extreme poverty. An important segment in rural areas are the 40 percent of peasants with properties between 7-15 hectares. They are poor peasants who sell an important part of their crops in the market and who, like their urban counterparts, are very vulnerable to climatic changes. Employment and Income Among the Sutiaba Employment dynamics among the Sutiabas does not differ from the general trends of the other poor in the Westem region. Unemployment is high and employment, when available, is restricted to low paid and unqualified jobs. In the urban area, about 44 percent of participants considered themselves as unemployed and about 20 percent did not have a permanent job. In total about 65 percent of respondents in urban Sutiaba were unemployed or held unstable jobs. Women Sutiabas are restricted to professions such as commnerce, maid services, teaching and nursing. The majority of Sutiabas women who do not work define themselves as housewives rather than unemployed. According to one participant: "I haven 't had a job since 1990; Idon 't even lookfor ajob anymore because I can 'tfind any" (Sutiaba housewife). In urban areas, the economically active population for women is the same as that of men. Women also have lower incomes relative to men (a little over 50 percent of the price of a basic food basket for women as opposed to 70 percent for men). The middle-level technic4l/professional category for women in commerce is the only employment category that has above average income levels, although these incomes are only close to the price of the basic food basket. A significant proportion of women work as maids, which is one of the lowest paid jobs in the economy. In rural areas, the situation for women is even more difficult because they are not even recognized a farmers although most perform agricultural tasks alongside men. The majority of the rural-based economically active population works as small farmers or rural workers. The latter are mostly seasonally employed for about 5 to 6 months a year. All rural families grow basic crops such as beans and com usually on lands smaller than one manzana. Quantities of food produced are not enough to sustain the family, a situation that forces members of the family to seek alternate survival strategies such as selling firewood and working as day laborers or in construction jobs in exchange for food. The Sutiabas are organized in 18 cooperatives which sow about 2,600 hectares of corn, beans and sorgo annually. The cooperatives, however, do not generate permanent work year round for their members. Crops are grown using non-traditional technological levels and generally occupy members 6 months every year, leaving them unemployed for the remaining 6 months.
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Western Region Page 15 of 22 The Sutiabas and the Environment The Sutiabas have no experience managing forest areas nor has this concem been part of their tradition in light of the more pressing need for survival. Sutiaba territory lacks important forest areas except fbr a few patches of tropical dry woods. Forest destruction is caused mostly by cutting for domestic and commercial firewood. Almost 82 percent of RRA participants use firewood for cooking. Social Organization Among the Sutiabas Social capital among the Sutiabas is high-about 48 percent of RRA participants are members of community organizations. Although gender differences are small, more men are organized than women. The largest organization is the ndigenous Community; 55 percent of RRA participants reported belonging to the Indigenous Community, of which a slightly higher proportion were urban-based. The second most important form of organization are those related to development projects-17 percent of participants claimed that they were members of these types of groups. The traditional Sutiaba organizations are the Junta Directiva de la Comunidad Indigena, the Consejo de Ancianos, the Consejos Comunales, and the Juntas de Cementerio. Characteristics of these organizations are as follows: • The Junta Directiva is elected by popular vote for a two-year mandate, although government regulations state that elections should be annual. As a result of the economic, social and political changes that affected the ethnic composition of the Sutiaba communities, the Sutiabas require only kinship as a basis for membership in the community. Thus, voting rights are given to any individual who has been residing in the comnmunity for more than seven years whenever they accept and identify with the Sutiabas' indigenous values, even in the absence of Sutiaba ancestry. From a political and administrative point of view, this is the indigenous organization with the largest mandate, although it does not constitute a pure form of autonomous local governrment. Both urban and rural Sutiabas are under the jurisdiction of the municipality of Leon. * The Junta Directiva is not a traditional Sutiaba organization although it was created by the Sutiabas to deal with issues related to the indigenous community. Its origins relate to the Sutiabas process of incorporation in Le6n. Most likely the organizational structure started as a mechanism promoted by government and local landowners to counter indigenous land disputes which had been led by traditional indigenous organizations like the Consejo de Ancianos. Basic activities of the Junta Directiva are: mediating community relationships with the city administration and the central government; administering community land; coordinating activities with different indigenous organizations; and representing the Sutiabas in the Coordination of Nicaraguan Indigenous Communities. It has also promoted activities in the area of social, economic and cultural development.
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Western Region Page 16 of 22 But the Junta Directiva 's main asset in the moral authority won during land disputes. The Junta is recognized by the Sutiabas as their moral and political authority even though this role has been weakened in recent years by political polanzation. * The Consejo deAncianos was the highest authority in the community before the Spanish colonization and has remained so despite attempts by past governments and colonial powers to weaken this organizational structure. The council virtually disappeared in the first half of the twentieth century, but reappeared in the 80s due to interest among the people and particularly the efforts of the Junta Directiva. The Consejo de Ancianos is an autonomous moral authority with approximately 35 members who are elders in the community. Members must be born in Sutiaba, belong to old famnilies of conununal tradition, be recognized as an advocate of communal land property, have been a member of the Junta Directiva, and have an untarnished reputation. * The Consejos Comunales are neighborhood organizations with representatives elected at the vicinity-level. Their rnain responsibility is to respond to social demands of residents. * The Juntas de Cementerio are in charge of maintaining and managing five community cemeteries as well as observing religious traditions and Holy Week rituals. Traditional productive organizations no longer exist among the Sutiaba. The cooperatlvas, which are presently the most usual model of productive organization in the community, emerged in 1979. Each of the 18 Sutiaba cooperatives has an average of 17 members, who are mostly urban based. Eleven of the cooperatives are part of the UCAIS (Uni6n de las Cooperativas Indigenas de Sutiaba), which provide associate members with technical assistance, storage, marketing and legal and bookkeeping advice. UCAIS has the best capacity for economic management in the community. In addition to the advice it provides to associate members, UCAIS operates a number of other programs including a program for female farmers; the Asociaci6n de Ganaderos de Sutiaba (ASOGASA), which is a small association of members who own lands outside the Sutiaba territory limits; and the Fondo Revolvente de Credito Xuchiall, which is revolving loan fund for productive activities. This fund was created by the Junta Directiva de la Comunidad and the Nicaraguan Institute for Investigations and Popular Education (INIEP). Until 1995, it had provided financing to 122 families, 79 percent of which were female single- headed. A team of indigenous Sutiaba professionals manage the fund. The two most important organizations that work with women and youth among the Sutiabas are: The Fundacion para el Desarrollo Integral de la Mujer Indigena "Xochitl Acatl " which receives support from European funds and UNICEF to work
 Annex 3 Social Asssmnt: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Western Region Page 17 of 22 with women. Funds support informal credit for poultry production, vegetable gardens, cattle and reforestation. To this date, 47 female single-heads of household have benefited from resources for productive activities. Funds also offer educational programs in health, family planning, pre-natal and infant care, and sanitation. In cooperation with the Universidad Nacional Aut6noma and cooperating physicians, the Foundation supports clinical activities which have benefited an average of 290 patients a month in traditional medicine and 240 in non-traditional medicine. Other programs for women and youth at risk include education in sexuality, fertility, sexually transmitted diseases, solidarity and equality. The Movimiento de J6venes Indigenas "Hringue Nidi Ruis" (Children of the Sun) offers program in health, water, electricity, education, enviromnent, culture and sports. Major sources of funding include UNDP and UNFPA for the project on Recreation and Attention Centers for Sutiaba Adolescents (CARAS). Tlhe presence of non govermnental organizations in the Sutiaba territory is weak except for the ones mentioned above. CARE, CIPRES and CEPAD also support small susainable projects in water, agriculture and irrigation in a few districts. 6. CONCLUSIONS The main conclusions of the Social Assessment are as follows: (a) Rural areas of the Western region show the poorest social indicators. In contrast with urban areas, poverty in rural zones is greater, opportunities are fewer, educational levels are worse, and there is less access to infrastructure services. Health and education facilities, sanitation, roads, and access to local markets are unsatisfactory in many areas. (b) Rural households are more crowded and have a higher dependency ratio than in urban ones. The proportion of children in poverty is high in the entire region, and higher in rural than in urban areas. Children are an at-risk population group. (c) In the project area, the main gender issues are: (i) single-headed households, which tend to be female, tend to be poorer than conjugally-headed households; (iii) both men and women play a role in the survival strategies of the poor but women have a particularly critical position because they are responsible for most single-headed households and often provide for conjugally-headed families during periods of scarcity; (iv) the gender division of labor on the farm and in the household imply that technology, extension and training needs among men and women vary; (v) men and women use natural resources differently and therefore also have different priorities in environmental activities; (vi) educational levels among women tends to be lower than among men which, in tum, affects women's ability to participate in project activities;
 Annex 3 Social Assessment: Poverty, Gender and Indigenous Issues in the Western Region Page 18 of 22 and (vii) men and women have different forms of organization which affects their access to information and resources. (d) The rural poor, including the Sutiaba rural poor, are predominantly small farmers, often landless. Frequently, households live off properties of less than 3.5. Productivity is low and access to markets is difficult. (e) Two interrelated factors cause poverty: first, the small size of property coupled with extremely low productivity from inappropriate technologies and lack of financing; and second, the absence of off-farm employment opportunities for the poor. (f) According to the poor, poverty results from lack of employment, low agricultural productivity and limited access markets. Based on their diagnosis of poverty, the priorities of the poor are: first, projects oriented to support agricultural production; and second, health services. Water supply is a priority for both agricultural needs and family consumption. The environment is not seen a priority because is it not perceived as a constraint to poverty. (g) The sense of hopelessness that prevails arnong the poor is often compensated by a cultural disposition for social solidarity. The poor in the project area are well organized. They participate in community groups such as the cornites comarcales, cooperatives, women's associations, Sutiaba cooperatives, NGOs, and project groups. Foreign donors, however, largely mobilized and sustain these community organizations. (h) The main problems of the Sutiabas are land disputes. However a vast portion of the Sutiaba land is under conmmunity control and this control cannot be legally challenged. This includes cooperative land legalized by the governnent. Indigenous leaders requested that the project prioritize women because their experience shows these investments produce greater benefits to the family. Rural projects are of little interest to urban-based Sutiaba because they are for the most part city dwellers. 7. To enhance men's and women's participation, the project would train staff on how to detect gender differences and constraints to participation, and how to develop strategies for overconiing gender barriers in the project. (j) Project Promotion. The project would ensure that promotional material and communications channels reflect gender differences and constraints. Specifically, materials would avoid gender stereotypes in visual displays and text and portray men and women as equal participants in the project. The project would design a promotional and communications strategy for men and women based on the following information in project areas: (a) specific local gathering spots for men and women; (b) frequently used or accessible forms of mass media for men and women; (c) time that men and women use media channels; and (d) traditional means of communication. It is expected that the project will establish a door to door promotional campaign to ensure both men and women are invited to introductory meetings and microplanning sessions. If societal norms inhibit women's participation with men, the project will gather men and women separately and train community men and women on gender issues to avoid possible conflicts. (k) Participatory Planning and Subproject Implementation. The project would use a participatory planning methodology with a gender perspective to ensure that both men and women have access to municipal funds and are involved in determining community priorities and planning and executing subprojects. The methodology will consider: gender-based social divisions in the cosnmunity; time schedules of men and women; gender differences in geographical mobility; literacy, education and training differences in men and women; and organizational capacity and legal status of men's and women's groups. (I) The project will encourage female participation through their own organizations in situations where men dominate and have greater influence in conmmunity organizations, but will work towards mainstreaming women in community groups by training women in organization, leadership and self- esteem and training men on gender issues. The project will also schedule activities to coincide with time and geographical limitations faced by men and women (e.g. on Sundays following or before religious services). (m) Training and Capacity Building at the Community Level. The project will support training programs to compensate for illiteracy among community members which in tum impedes participation in the project (particularly on the part of women). Training and information disseniination will involve means other than written materials (such as oral communications tools) to avoid illiteracy obstacles. The project will recruit trainers and intermediary

Component I: Rural MuniciDalities Develonment Background and Rationale The rural municipalities development component was designed to respond to: (1) the need to strengthen local institutions in rural areas: local governments, NGOs and communities; (2) the need to foster economic growth in rural areas where most of the poor are located; (3) the need to directly provide support to the poorest men and women; and (4) the need to conserve and restore critical natural resources and protect the local environment. There were several key considerations underlying the design of this component: (1) in Nicaragua local institutions are closer to problems of, internalize better and can be more easily made accountable to the needs of the rural poor; (2) with the proper incentives local institutions can be more efficient in practicing sustainable management of natural resources; (3) lagging rural investment is partially due to a local financing system that benefits large urban centers and that has prevented local rural institutions from developing their decision- making capacity; (4) given the current assistance programs to reform central government agencies focusing them on normative aspects there is a need to decentralize the delivery of local public services and goods; (5) key institutions such as the FISE and NRDP that presently deliver local investments have a limited time horizon and can only be sustained with a permanent flow of aid resources; there is a need for long term sustainable alternatives to them; (6) there is cumulative evidence from Brazil, Bolivia, Mexico and Colombia that if properly designed, systems for delivering rural development services and addressing rural poverty through local governments can be quite successful; (7) Nicaragua's strategy as reflected in the Partial Reform to the Constitution of 1995, in the work of the Decentralization Commission of Government and in various laws and regulations is to increasingly shift more resources and decision power to local governments; and (8) local governments already have large responsibilities over sustainable development in their jurisdictions. Objectives The objective of this component is to establish a mechanism based on municipal governments and community organizations for reducing rural poverty through rural investment in economic infrastructure, improved natural resource management and small-scale communal productive activities. I This Annex describes some project features that are described in more detail in the following documents in the project file: Plan de Implementaci6n del Proyecto, Reglamento Operativo, Manual de Capacitaci6n and Plan Operacional para 1996/1997.

(A) Institutional Development of Municipalities (US$5.8 million) The objective of this subcomponent is to create the minimum technical and managerial capacity at the municipal level to assist the rural poor, manage natural resources and protect the environment, to support local economic development through public goods; to manage the Community and Municipality Subprojects Subcomponent; and to manage the funds that will be forthcoming later as part of the system of fiscal transfers for disadvantaged municipalities. The sub-component includes two activities: (1) Creation/strengthening of Municipal Technical Units; and (2) Training and technical assistance on project management and municipal affairs. All project municipalities have been classified relative to each other into one of three categories (high-A, moderate-B, and low capacity-C) based on their administrative and financial capacities and the presence of other enabling elements, e.g., NGOs, development committees, etc. (see Table Al. 1). Municipal Technical Units Each municipal government would create a Municipal Technical Unit responsible for project activities at the local level. The minimnum staffing of the MTU would include (1) a project's specialist (engineer, agronomist, etc,); (2) a participation specialist; and (3) an accountant/financial specialist. These staff could be existing staff assigned to those specific tasks (in type A municipalities), new staff (in type C municipalities), or a combination (in type B municipalities).(See Table Al. 1 for classification). One of these staff would be nominated Local Project Coordinator and would be the main contact person for project activities. The project would finance minor equipment and office upgrading, consultants, incremental salaries and other recurrent costs to assist municipal with the following activities: (1) recruitment of staff for and physical establishment of the MTUs; (2) operation of MTUs for the execution of activities (1) to (13) below; (3) setting-up a subproject monitoring and evaluation system; and (4) setting-up a system of financial controls and project accounts at the municipal level. The functions of the MTU (see Operational Manual), would include: (1) promoting the project with beneficiaries; (2) assisting communities set up and operate the Intercommunity Assembly and the Community Supervision Committee; (3) promoting, training and assisting Intercommunity Assembly with participatory planning; (4) preparing municipal investment plans (MIP) including financial cronogram; (5) assisting communities and municipalities with project preparation;

The project would finance consultants, seminars, workshops, study tours and other training expenses for the MTUs and other municipal staff in the following thematic areas: (1) the subproject cycle, including on the identification, preparation, appraisal, implementation and operation of subprojects in various thematic areas; (2) participatory methods including participatory planning; (3) environment and land use plans and design and planning of rural development, natural resources and enviromment programs; (4) gender and indigenous peoples related issues; (5) accounting, auditing and financial management related to the project and municipal operation in general; (6) subproject monitoring, evaluation and reporting; (7) procurement for works, goods and consultants and NGOs at the local level; (8) local revenue generation and cost recovery for maintenance activities; (9) personnel recruitment and management; (10) municipal administration; (11) legal assistance Agreement to receive training and/or technical assistance in the thematic areas (1) through (7) would be a condition of municipal eligibility for the Community and Municipality Subprojects Sub-component. (B) Information, Participation and Training (USS2.8 million) The objectives of this subcomponent are (1) to make the rights and responsibilities of communities and local governments widely known to increase the level of community
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 4 of 21 control and local transparency and accountability; (2) to increase the supply of local technical services to support communities and municipalities; and (3) to generate increased demand for subprojects. This sub-component includes three activities: (1) promotion and dissemination of project; (2) creation and operation of community participatory structures and participatory planning; and (3) training of community leaders, NGOs and local consultants. There would be two kinds of communities eligible for participatory planning and to propose projects. For most population community would be defined as the "comarca" which is the smallest geographical unit commonly recognized in Nicaragua. A typical comarca includes about 100 families, while a municipality could have about 50 comarcas. For indigenous communities, the indigenous traditional community structures would be treated as commnunities for project purposes. Promotion and dissemination of project at the local level The project would finance consultants, dissemination materials, seminars, workshops and travel expenses for the promotion and dissemination of the project at the community level through town meetings, radio, TV, videos, written materials, other infornal communication devices and seminars and workshops for community members, leaders and notables. Promotion and dissemination activities would take place periodically and would include at least the following thematic areas: (1) Overall project description including objectives, components, resources and responsibilities, aspects of operational manual and cronogram of implementation; (2) Community participation aspects including commnunity participatory structures and participatory planning; (3) Women and indigenous peoples issues; (4) Environmental issues including role of environmental and land use plans; (5) Examples of project successes and failures in other communities including types of subprojects approved, procurement arrangements, subproject costs, etc. Promotion and dissemination activities would be the joint responsibility of MTUs and INIFOM, which would recruit NGOs or consultants to assist with the process and develop dissemination materials. A community member would be designated as project promoter at the community level and would be the community focal point for promotion and dissemination. Intercommunity Assembly and Community Supervision Committee and Participatory Planning The project would finance consultants and travel expenses to assist with the creation and/or operation of the Intercommunity Assembly and the Community Supervision Committee and with participatory planning events. The Intercommunity Assembly is the key community structure at the municipal level. It is composed of community representatives (comprising at least 70% of all the communities within a municipality) and may include also representatives of local NGOs,
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 5 of 21 religious groups, producer associations, and local notables (priest, teacher, nurse, etc.) . The key functions of the Intercommunity Assembly are: (1) to priorize the needs of the various communities into an overall expression of community needs and priorities at the municipal level and to solve conflicts between different communities for project resources; (2) to define the general strategy for rural development; (3) to discuss, endorse and support the Municipal Investment Plan to be financed by the project; (4) to elect members of the Community Supervision Committee and to review their reports. The Community Supervision Committee is a small structure in charge of ensuring that community interests and the interests of rural areas are adequately taken into account. It will have the same number of members as tiue Municipal Council. Each member will be elected for one year. The project will pay a small fixed fee per member for each meeting attended to cover travel expenses and opportunity costs of labor. The key functions of the Community Supervision Committee are: (1) supervise project execution at the municipal level on behalf of communities; (2) report to the Intercommunity Assembly and INIFOM on project execution and issue certificates of sub-project completion to the MTU and INIFOM; (3) oversee municipality/community agreements and compliance with project objectives. The activities related to the establishment and operation of the Intercommunity Assembly and Community Supervision Committee would be jointly executed by the MTUs and INIFOM, which would recruit consultants to assist with the process. Participatory planning would be the process for prioritizing community problems and needs and start suggesting solutions to these problems. Participatory planning would be carried out by the community with facilitators which would include both the MTU and consultants or NGOs recruited by INIFOM to assist with the process. Community members would meet to carry out participatory planning exercises to agree on needs and investment priorities and to elect community representatives to the Intercommunity Assembly (IA). The MTU would integrate priorities of each community within each municipality into a municipal investment plan (MIP), which could include also projects identified by one or more municipal governments. The MTUs would also take into account recommendations from the Environment and Land Use Plans (ELUP). MIPs would be submitted to the Intercommunity Assembly (IA) for discussion and priorization of investments among communities. The Community Supervision Committee (CSC) would be responsible for advising the municipal government, monitoring the implementation of the municipal investment plan and informing conmmunities of progress. The MIPs would be approved by Municipal Councils and submitted to the Regional Delegation of INIFOM for non-objection and confirmation of eligibility for IDA financing or for other financing sources.

Restrictions on subprojects. Consistently with the project's focus on rural development through the provision of local public goods, poverty alleviation and environmental protection, the following restrictions would apply:
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 9 of 21 (1) subprojects in towns of more than 10,000 inhabitants do not qualify; (2) at least 60% of funds invested annually are for sub-projects outside of the head town of the municipality; (3) activities of second-level organizations (e.g., NGOs, governnent line agencies, universities, private sector firms, etc) which are not first requested by and directly linked to municipalities, communities or community-level groups do not qualify; (4) activities which could cause irreversible environmental damage (e.g., conversion of forest to other uses; drainage of wetlands; channelization of rivers and streams; use of agrochemicals with a WHO rating of 'A') would not qualify; (5) beneficiaries must be community organizations or groups of at least 10 households; individual activities do not qualify; (6) subprojects otherwise financeable by banks or other lending institutions do not qualify; compliance with this restriction would be checked during project audits and supervision; (7) the maximum cost per beneficiary is US$700. Subproject cycle. Responsibilities over the subproject cycle would be the following: (1) Subproject identification The project ideas would have been defined and pre- approved in the MIPs. The MTUs would assist communities with further identification of projects for which the services of local private consultants, NGOs or government officials qualified through the registry of service providers could be contracted. The identification phase would also include defining the Project User Group (PUG), those community members with a stake in the subproject and that later would supervise or execute its implementation, operation and maintenance. (2) Subproject preparation Subproject preparation would be the responsibility of the MTUs for municipality subprojects or MTUs and/or PUGs for community subprojects. In most instances MTUs and legally established communities would hire qualified private consultants, NGOs or government agencies to assist communities and MTUs with project preparation. Projects would cover the costs of consultants or travel expenses of government staff. Projects would be prepared according to guidelines included in the Training Manual and the project proposal would need to include a (a) management plan; (b) operation, maintenance and, if the case, cost recovery plan; (c) technical assistance plan; (d) co-financing p!an identifying sources of financing; (e) simple monitorable indicators; and (f) the sub-project agreement and other signed letters and agreements depending on the case and according to the formats in the Operational Manual (Reglamento Interno).
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 10of21 (3) Subproject appraisal and approval. The Municipal Technical Unit would review all project proposals and recommend to the Municipal Council approval, rejection or further preparation. The MC would approve all subprojects that: (a) meet community priorities as outlined in MPs; (b) include acceptable management, operation, cost recovery and technical assistance plans; (c) include criteria for monitoring and evaluation; (d) are technically sound; (e) include co-financing by beneficiaries and/or municipalities; (f) meet environmental criteria; (g) fit poverty objectives; and (h) target rural areas. All projects of US$25,000 or less would not require further approval. All projects of US$50,000 of graduated municipalities would not require further approval. Projects not under those thresholds would have to be approved by INIFOM and environmentally cleared by MARENA. For the appraisal of projects INIFOM would request the assistance of line agencies - INTA, NRDP, INAA, FISE, MCT. - and could also recruit consultants to assist with the appraisal. (4) Subproject implementation. Subproject implementation would also be the responsibility of the MTUs and communities. Projects could be either implemented by legally established communities themselves, by contractors recruited by the MTUs on behalf of communities, or by a combination of the two. Project implementation would in specific cases include training on project operation, maintenance and cost recovery. All projects would be supervised by the MTU and communities and/or Project User Groups established. All projects greater than US$50,000 and samples of smaller projects would be also supervised by the Regional Delegation of INIFOM. (5) Operation, maintenance and cost recovery. Operation, maintenance and cost-recovery would be the responsibility of legally established communities and/or municipal governments depending on the project and the particular model to be adopted would be described in the project proposal. For the specific case of productive projects, cost-recovery into community funds would be promoted and the project would finance technical assistance and training on the management of these funds. These rotating funds would be the mechanisms for spreading the benefits of private goods projects over the largest number of community members in order to avoid conflicts and build up the social capital in communities. Financing Ceilings. Financing ceilings play three roles: (1) by imposing a budget constraint on municipal governments and communities they would force these to prioritize and optimize their portfolio and to develop trade-off analysis and conflict resolution mechanisms, in the process helping strengthen local decision-making structures; (2) they would avoid biasing funding toward the larger and better situated municipalities which are more capable of presenting sound subproject proposals; and (3) they would permit to better target project resources toward meeting poverty and environmental objectives. Each year there would be a financing ceiling per municipality calculated on the basis of a formula applied to a total annual budget that increases from the first to the last year of the project. The results (in percentage) are presented in Figure A1. 1. These caps will be reviewed and modified annually based on performance and demand. The indicators and their weights are: (1) poverty index, using the FISE index of "unsatisfied basic needs" - 42%; (2) necessity index, using municipality's rural population as a proxy for necessity - 34%; (3) economic efficiency index using as proxies: municipal tax collections - 14%; and the total community counterpart (in-kind and cash) from previous year's municipal development investment program - 10%. Component II. Natural Resources Policy and Institutions Background and Rationale The Natural Resources Policies and Institutions Component was designed to increase the capacity at the central government level to ensure that public and private actors internalize environmental concerns in their decisions. This is particularly important in the context of the decentralization process to local governments and communities supported by component I. Local institutions are known for inadequately considering the costs of their actions on other jurisdictions, and this is particularly so in the case of the environment where there are substantial regional, national and global externalities. Hence it is necessary for central government to keep track of these effects and through a variety of instruments prevent local jurisdictions from taking actions that cause more harm on others than the benefits that accrue to them. The second important consideration in the design of both this component and of component III - the associated Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor Project to be financed by GEF - was to assist government in putting in place a legal and institutional framework that would create the necessary conditions, as stated in Bank policies, for future Bank supported investment projects in the natural resources sectors, and in particular in forestry and coastal zone management. Objectives The key objective of this component is to ensure that GON and local institutions and communities take into account important regional, national and global
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 17 of 21 environment aspects in their decisions by improving the policy and institutional framework for natural resources. Component Description This component consists of a small technical assistance program covering two different areas: (A) strengthening of MARENA; and (B) interinstitutional assistance program. (A) Strengthening of MARENA (US$3.0 million) The objective of this subcomponent is to increase the institutional capacity of MARENA in the areas of (1) policy; (2) environmental planning and monitoring; and (3) protected area management. The environmental planning and monitoring activities would help develop an information system identifying critical environmental risks at the local level that will be used to assist municipal governments with their investment decisions under component I and that will enable MARENA to object to risky investments for the environment in the context of components I and III. Component III. Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor Background and Rationale The Atlantic slope of Nicaragua is biologically an extremely rich area of lowland tropical rain forests, coastal wetlands, pine savannas, and higher altitude pine- oak forests. These ecoregions and ecosystems have high global importance on their own merits, but in addition, they form part of a critical link in a larger Mesoamerican Biological Corridor (MBC) linking North America, Central America, and South America. Although this area in Nicaragua is one of the most intact natural areas remaining in Central America, there is no assurance that key components will be protected in the long-term as part of a viable protected areas system. It is now threatened by colonists spilling over to the Atlantic from Nicaragua's more densely inhabited Pacific slope. The Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor (ABC) represents the Nicaraguan portion of the Mesoamerican Biological Corridor. Support for an ABC has long been a national priority in Nicaragua. The Tropical Forestry Action Plan and the National Environmental Action Plan, both completed in the early 1990's, explicitly recognized the importance of strengthening protected areas in the Atlantic slope and maintaining the intactness of this last large area of natural habitat in Central America. Nicaragua's Ministry of the Environment (MARENA) has issued a draft version of the country's Biodiversity Strategy and this document is now undergoing a process of public consultation. The Strategy document identifies the ABC as a top national biodiversity priority. There is widespread concern among national, regional, and local governments that the current patterns of frontier development on the Atlantic slope are unsustainable, non-economic and are the source of substantial social problems. Moreover, there is insufficient control over logging and mining concessions in the region, in part because Nicaragua has not yet put in place the legal and institutional framework to minimize environmental risks from these activities, which could become potentially important in the Atlantic. More importantly there are serious issues of indigenous land and natural resources tenure. Large portions of these ecoregions in the proposed ABC are presently included in protected areas. However, in most of these protected areas, there are no management activities, protection is weak or non-existent, the legal status is unclear, there is legal confusion over indigenous rights and responsabilities and the actual boundaries on the ground are ill-defined and unmarked. Support for protected areas and their buffer zones in this part of Nicaragua is being provided by a variety of donors and aid agencies including USAID, GTZ, the European Union, the Danish, Dutch, Canadian, and Austrian governnents, The Nature Conservancy (TNC), World Wildlife Fund (WWF), the Caribbean Conservation Corporation, and others.
 Annex 4 Project Description Page 20 of 21 Objectives This component (associated project) seeks to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of the biodiversity resources of an Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor (ABC) through the Atlantic slope of Nicaragua. Such a corridor would be a critical link in a larger Mesoamerican Biological Corridor (MBC). The Nicaraguan ecoregions and ecosystems within the proposed ABC have high global importance on their own merits and as a whole, represent the most intact natural habitats remaining in Central America. Component Description To achieve the objectives outlined above, the proposed project is organized into three components. The definition of the ABC itself is one face of a multi-faceted land use strategy for the entire Atlantic slope. This planning exercise, taking into account both biological and socioeconormic considerations, is currently being undertaken with GON and GEF Project Development Fund (PDF) resources. The three components are: (A) Involvement of Local Communities, Indigenous Groups, NGOs and Governments in Biodiversity Management The project would finance consultants and training for: (i) development of and promoting the project with indigenous and non-indigenous communities in the Atlantic region; (ii) training indigenous and non-indigenous communities in sustainable biodiversity use and protection; (iii) assisting indigenous committees in pursuing formal recognition for their land and natural resources rights; (iv) training and technical assistance to NGOs, and municipal and regional governments for the implementation of the ABC strategy; and (v) training of central government agencies on the ABC strategy. An Indigenous Peoples Development Plan (IPDP) is currently under preparation. (B) Biodiversity Planning, Information, Monitoring and Evaluation The project would finance equipment, consultants, studies, workshops, training and dissemination materials, travel expenses and incremental salaries and other recurrent costs for (i) continuing the ABC planning activities; (ii) implementing a biodiversity monitoring system in coordination with communities and local and regional governments to warn of threats to biodiversity; and (iii) establishing a system for evaluating potential impacts on the ABC of development activities such as roads and other infrastructure and logging, mining and fishing concessions and for proposing and enforcing mitigating measures. (C) Financial Mechanism for the Sustainability of the ABC2 The project would finance equipment, consultants, training, workshops, seminars, studies and study tours for: (i) the operation of a financing mechanism to promote the long-term sustainability of the ABC including fund rising; and (ii) grants for sub-projects covering the following themes: 2 The nature of the financing mechanism Nill be defined during preparation of this component.

 NICARAGUA RURAL MUNICIPALITIES PROJECT ANNEX 5 INDIGENOUS PEOPLES STRATEGY FOR THE ATLANTIC REGION 1. OVERVIEW OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES In 1993, the estimated indigenous population of Nicaragua was 231,727 inhabitants, representing 5.2 percent of the total. The greatest concentration of indigenous people is found in the Atlantic region where Miskito, Sumu, Rama and Garifona peoples live. The Miskito, with over 110,00 people, are the most numerous of indigenous peoples. In fact, in 1993, they represented over 58 percent of the population of the North Atlantic region and close to 48 percent of the total indigenous population of the country. In contrast, in the Pacific region, there are also several indigenous peoples, among them the Subtiaba, Monimb6, Matagalpa, Sebaco and Jinotega, but they are not as numerous as those in the Atlantic. In the heavily populated Pacific and Northern regions indigenous groups have had for a long timne to adapt to the dominant non-indigenous populations and have lost access to some of their traditional lands and cultural identity. In the Atlantic Coast, on the other hand, with a low population density and vast areas of pristine habitats, indigenous peoples for the most part still have access to their traditional territories and have been able to maintain the essence of their traditional lifestyles. A fundamental issue that needs to be solved in Nicaragua relates to indigenous land and natural resources rights. Clarifying these rights could go a long way in contributing to economic growth in Nicaragua. Until indigenous land and natural resources rights issues are solved in the resource rich Atlantic it will be impossible for Nicaragua to pursue careful exploitation and sustainable use of its minerals, forests and fishery. Potential investors will be scared away, resource values will not be maximized, and conflict and gridlock will prevent indigenous communities from benefiting fully from resource use and GON from enforcing important environmental regulations. The problem is not one of Nicaragua's willingness to advance in the recognition of indigenous land and natural resources rights. To the contrary, public statements and recent initiatives demonstrate that there is good will in working towards a solution to these problems. But due to the less acute social problems in the Atlantic and the formidable task of building a democracy in a war ravaged and very poor country, indigenous issues have not been a top priority and efforts have been channeled instead towards land tenure and titling, poverty alleviation and demobilization of soldiers elsewhere in the country. Moreover, given the limited capacity of specialized institutions to address the many policy and legal inconsistencies affecting indigenous peoples rights, advances have been slow.

OBSTACLES TO THE RECOGNITION OF INDIGENOUS LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES RIGHTS IN THE ATLANTIC' MARENA commissioned two studies to (i) identify main obstacles for advancing with the recognition of indigenous land and natural resource rights contemplated in the Constitution; and (ii) to propose a strategy/action plan for the government for removing those obstacles. These studies were commissioned as part of the Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the Atlantic which is required before appraisal of the GEF component (see below). The main conclusions/recommendations of these studies are briefly summarized below. The Legal And Institutional Context There are good prospects for the recognition of indigenous land and natural resources rights in the Atlantic: * There is a solid constitutional and legal basis in the Constitution and Autonomy Law of 1987 that guarantees the rights of indigenous communities of the Atlantic to their traditional territories and natural resources contained in them. - There is a clear political will, expressed by various GON agencies and the President of the Republic, to advance with the recognition of the traditional rights of indigenous communities over land and use and management of natural resources in those lands. * There is a high level of awareness in the indigenous communities themselves over their territorial rights as a historical and legal commitment of the State and an understanding that these rights entail substantial autonomy in the management of community matters and use and disposition of natural resources. * There is a clear political and administrative conscience of regional governments of the importance of recognizing traditional indigenous land rights consistently with historical commitments and existing norms. * There are solid indigenous organizations and indigenous representations at the level of municipal and regional governments that will facilitate the process of recognizing indigenous land claims. Main Limitations and Difficulties There are legal, admrinistrative, technical, socio-economic and cultural obstacles to advancing with the recognition of indigenous land and natural resources rights. I See background report in project file "Viabilidady Condiciones Legales de Cumplimiento de un Componente de Legalizaci6n de Tierras a las Comunidades Indigenas de la Costa Atldntica Dentro del Proyecto de Manejo de Recursos Naturales - IPDP" by Roque RoldAn, December 1995.
 Annex 5 Indigenous Peoples Strategy for the Atlantic Region Page 3 of 8 Legally the main obstacles are the following: * There is no legal scheme defined in the agrarian or indigenous legislation prior to the Constitution and Autonomy Law of 1987 for the administration of community lands, other than the one specified under the Civil Code and in various laws and decrees published since the beginning of the century and which were applied to the different situation of indigenous conmmunities of the Pacific. This Civil Code model (communal property) represents a contract between community members as co-owners of an asset, but is insufficient for the administration of a territory historically belonging to a culturally differentiated group, as is the case with communities in the Atlantic. The 1987 Autonomy Law, on the other hand, contemplated the indigenous community land property right as inalienable and indescriptable and not subject to sale, donation, seizure or attachment. * There is no clarity as to the competencies over property rights, use and management of natural resources between Central Government, regional governments and indigenous communities. There are, however, dispersed throughout various pieces of legislation, enough elements to permit a clarification of most legal issues affecting indigenous property and natural resources. Unfortunately this process of legal clarification has not yet taken place in Nicaragua. T [NRA is the public entity in charge of titling of agrarian lands and of redistributing national lands and "tierras baldfas". The agrarian reform titles issued by INRA have all the restrictions applicable cable to agrarian reform (size, intended use, etc.). However, in no agrarian legislation is INRA explicitly given responsibility over assigning commnunity lands to indigenous communities under community titles. Hence, although the 1995 Constitution and the 1987 Autonomy Law recognize indigenous rights, there is no agency explicitly in charge of executing community titles, nor have procedures been defined for demarcation and titling or certification. * There may exist discrepancies between the municipality, a geographic/administrative unit, and the indigenous territory, subject to its own community government, once these are created. * There may exist conflicts between community natural resources rights obtained through the process of recognition of community lands and the restrictions associated with various types of protected areas when these overlap with indigenous communities. * There are no clear procedures for granting juridical personality to communities. Administratively, lack of procedures for recognizing indigenous land titles creates a climate of uncertainty that affects key GON agencies with responsibilities that interact with indigenous communities in the Atlantic, namely INRA, MARENA, MAS and regional governments. Although all these institutions need to participate in the process of recognizing
 Annex 5 Indigenous Peoples Strategy for the Atlantic Region Page 4 of 8 community lands, the responsibilities and administrative roles of each one have not been defined. Technically, there is no definition of the traditional communal lands of each group nor an inventory of the Atlantic regarding its resources and most appropriate land use. This is important to estimate the size of the territories needed by communities to ensure subsistence. There are different views regarding the types of territorial or land rights that should be recognized to communities: by community, by ethnic group, by watershed. There is no definition of the most appropriate methods for measuring territories: traditional topography, aerophotography, mapping or a combination of these. Socially, there is no clarity over how to handle the cases of minority communities that have already lost some of their territories, either because traditional lands were assigned to settlers or occupied by other indigenous communities. There is an incomplete inventory, although some inforrnation does exist, about conflicts between different indigenous communities or groups of communities in particular regarding the use of trails and natural resources in the areas claimed. Such an inventory is essential for the definition of conflict resolution mechanisms as part of the procedures for legal recognition of indigenous land titles. Culturally, there is lack of information about the community organization and government that would facilitate the definition of the management model for lands under commnunity and the customary law management. Key recommendations for government The study's key recommendations for GON were the following: (1) To finalize the collection and analysis of legal instruments related to indigenous land and natural resource rights, including (i) treaties and agreements with foreign governments; (ii) Constitutional texts, laws, decrees and other legal initiatives of the State that affect the lifestyle of indigenous communities, and traditional forms of government and land tenure; (iii) decisions of the judicial system related to the rights of indigenous communities; (iv) official opinions of central government on the matter; and (v) agrarian legislation applied to indigenous communities of the Pacific. (partially done in background study) (2) To carry out a complete inventory of all land titles granted in the Atlantic for both indigenous and non-indigenous inhabitants and in particular titles granted under the Harrison-Altmirano Treaty, Agrarian Reform titles, and titles granted by the judicial system. (3) To carry out a compilation of customary law. (4) To conclude the diagnostics of the ethnic groups of the Atlantic initiated by INRA and MARENA. (5) To carry out an inventory of territories available to sustain the livelihoods of minority conmmunities such as the Sumus, Rama and Garifonas.
 Annex 5 Indigenous Peoples Strategy for the Atlantic Region Page 5 of 8 (6) To propose a law defining the property regime for indigenous conmnunities referred to in Article 107 of the Constitution (tentatively referred to in here as the Indigenous Land Law) and clarifying the rights that indigenous communities in their lands have over forests, water, wildlife, etc. (7) To clarify the responsibilities and obligations of indigenous commnunities, the regional government and MARENA in the administration of natural resources in indigenous lands and include these responsibilities in the proposed Indigenous Land Law and in legislation affecting natural resources. (8) To review various legislative initiatives related to natural resources (forestry, water, fisheries, protected areas, energy, etc.) to more precisely define aspects with implications for indigenous peoples and ensure consistency with their constitutional rights. (9) To define the procedures for legally recognizing indigenous land rights, defining responsibilities, community participation, etc., including procedures for legally recognizing indigenous communities. (10) To create a special structure involving several agencies under INRA leadership and including regional support committees and a technical support group in charge of preparing and reviewing proposals for decisions over the various indigenous land cases and to ensure coordination between the various GON agencies and regional governments in the process. 4. GOVERNMENT'S STRATEGY FOR DEALING WITH INDIGENOUS LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES RIGHTS Government's Action Plan GON is presently discussing the results of the studies mentioned above as well as other similar studies commissioned by INRA and plans to carry out workshops to generate a broad consensus over priorities for action and assignment of institutional responsibilities for their execution. This Action Plan, expected to be completed before appraisal of the GEF project, and to constitute an integral part of the Indigenous Peoples Development Plan being prepared under the GEF component, would be supported by IDA through country dialogue in the context of the CAS due in 1997, and by on-going and proposed operations namely (i) the Agricultural Technology and Land Management Project (Credit No. 2536-NI); (ii) the Nicaragua Indigenous Peoples IDF Grant No. 028902; (iii) the proposed IDA financed project; and (iv) the proposed GEF financed project. Preparation funds for the GEF project would help finance the workshops for the preparation of the Action Plan. Country dialogue The issue of how to support GON in the medium-term (1997-2000) in advancing with the recognition of indigenous land rights would be discussed in the context of the Country Assistance Strategy due in FY97. If needed and agreed by GON and IDA the FY97 CAS would more specifically detail the future IDA strategy for assisting GON with this issue.

INRA is likely to be the lead agency chosen for advancing with this issue although it needs to be supported through a higher level comrnmission including other GON agencies, narnely MARENA, MAS, INETER and Regional Governments and representatives of key stakeholders. INRA is presently reprogramming its activities in the context of the on-going project to give a higher priority to indigenous land titling during its second phase, which is about to start. Indigenous Peoples IDF Grant No. 028902 The Indigenous Peoples Grant being implemented by MAS includes training and workshops for indigenous peoples on a variety of issues. Aspects of indigenous land and natural resources rights are being included in the thematic topics covered. Proposed IDA and GEF projects As discussed elsewhere in this report the proposed project includes two distinct operations to be processed under separate project cycles: the Municipal Development Component and the Natural Resources and Policies Component, to be supported by IDA, and the Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor Component, to be supported by GEF. For ease of exposition the IDA components will be referred to as the IDA project and the ABC component as the GEF project. Geographically the proposed IDA project is split between the Westem Region (Le6n and Chinandega), where 90% of the community investments would take place, and the Atlantic Region with 10% or US$2.5 million ear-mark-ed for community development activities. The GEF project would take place entirely in the Atlantic and would be the main mechanisms for channeling funds for this region. The reason for the split of the IDA project is because IDA project funds are needed for the Atlantic for assistance to indigenous conmmunities with their development needs. Only 10% are allocated to the Atlantic because the region is sparsely populated, people are less poor than in the Western region, and local implementation capacity is more limited. Consistently with the proposed calendar for the IDA and GEF projects, GON decided during preparation to carry out a Social Assessment/Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the IDA project focused on Leon and Chinandega. The Social Assessment/Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the Atlantic would be carried out as part of preparation for the GEF project. This split was necessary in light of the different timing of the two operations and the need to better define the GEF project, including the delineation of the biodiversity corrioor, before a meaningful Social Assessment/IPDP could be developed. IDA disbursements for subprojects in the Atlantic would be conditional on the GEF project becoming effective, including the subrnission to IDA/GEF of an acceptable Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the Atlantic.
 Annex 5 Indigenous Peoples Strategy for the Atlantic Region Page 7 of 8 Proposed GEF project The GEF project would benefit indigenous communities as well as benefit from their activities. Sustainable use of natural resources by indigenous peoples is consistent with conservation of biodiversity and indigenous peoples would benefit from increased environmental protection since this would reduce the threats on their resources from logging, mining and fishing interests. The GEF project, which includes protected areas in the Atlantic, raises some issues, however, related to indigenous peoples traditional natural resource use rights in the context of biodiversity protection inside and outside of protected areas, and thus includes two specific components to address these issues. First, protection of biodiversity in indigenous traditional territories inside or outside protected areas in the Atlantic would be achieved through quid pro quo agreements with indigenous communities which have historical rights to vast areas to be included in the biodiversity corridor. Second, a project component would finance activities to involve indigenous communities in biodiversity protection and to assist them with community land demarcation and natural resource management plans. The Social Assessment/Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the Atlantic would comprise four main parts: (i) an analysis of the legal framework affecting indigenous peoples, review of their organizations and institutional responsibilities, already completed (see report entitled "Viabilidad y Condiciones Legales de Cunmplimiento de un Componente de Legalizacion de Tierras a las Comunidades Indigenas de la Costa Atl6ntica dentro del Proyecto de Manejo de Recursos Naturales" by Roque Roldan summarized above); (ii) an Action Plan being developed by GON through workshops for prioritizing next steps in addressing the legal constraints mainly for land titling and assigning institutional responsibilities for their execution (see above); (iii) a participation plan to fully involve indigenous communities in the design and implementation of the GEF component; and (iv) a social assessment including rapid rural appraisals of non-indigenous communities in the Atlantic and a participation plan for these communities. Proposed IDA project The proposed IDA project does not pose noticeable risks for indigenous communities. On the contrary, although not specifically targeting indigenous communities, it has built in mechanisms to give indigenous communities equal access to the project's resources as non-indigenous communities and to support and strengthen all rural communities. Nevertheless a Social Assessment/Indigenous Peoples Development Plan for the Sutiaba community in Leon was carried out during the preparation of the proposed project to improve the design of the participatory mechanisms included in the project. The results of the Social Assessment/IPDP for Leon and Chinandega were summarized in Annex 3. The technical assistance program to be managed by MARENA would include improving the policy framework for natural resources including contributions to legislative proposals under discussion in Nicaragua consistent with the constitutional rights of indigenous communities and the constitutional principles of decentralization. The results of the studies and analysis to be supported by the project would be disseminated, consulted and discussed through workshops and other events with civic society. The IDA project would support a
 Annex 5 Indigenous Peoples Strategy for the Atlantic Region Page 8 of 8 person in MARENA in charge of participation and relations with NGOs and an indigenous expert responsible for interaction with indigenous commnunities. The technical assistance program (IDA and GEF) would also finance a land use plan for the Atlantic that would include land use potentials and a preliminary identification of indigenous traditional territories (IDA project budget:USS 120,000). This plan, which would be approved by INETER, the agency officially responsible for demarcation of indigenous territories, would be extensively consulted and discussed with indigenous communities and regional governnents. The program also includes budget for studies of social and indigenous issues to be carried out during the project's first year (total budget US$155,000). The possibility of extending the IDA project investment activities (Rural Municipalities Development Component) to the entire RAAN and RAAS for the benefit of indigenous communities was included in project design (total budget: US$2.3 million) subject to the GEF project becoming effective, and the submission to IDA of an Indigenous Peoples Development Plan. An Environmental and Land Use Plan acceptable to IDA is also scheduled to be completed by December 31, 1997. Although financial resources are not the key constraint to the process of recognizing indigenous land and natural resource rights, the proposed IDA project would make funds available to communities for a wide range of subprojects to be proposed by the communities themselves, including technical and legal assistance for the elaboration of community demarcation and natural resource management proposals. These funds would be available both to indigenous communities in the Atlantic region and to the Sutiaba in Le6n. This project component also includes funds for training indigenous and non-indigenous commnunities on a wide range of topics and for participation, dissemination and information activities for which indigenous communities would be eligible. Project annual reviews would include assessments of progress made in the preparation/implementation of the IPDP.
 NICARAGUA RURAL MUNICIPALITIES PROJECT ANNEX 6 SUMMARY OF ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND MITIGATION PLAN The proposed project is essentially beneficial to the environment since its objectives include improving the policy and institutional framework for natural resources, improving natural resource management at the local level, reducing the pressures on the Atlantic frontier and protecting biodiversity in the Atlantic through the associated GEF project. Environmental risks posed by the project, although minor, are associated with some of the sub-project categories to be financed and the decentralization process to be supported by the project. A mitigation plan for sub-projects was included in the sub-project cycle and is described in Annex 4 and in the Operational Manual. An important instrument for managing environmental risks would be the Environment and Land Use Plans (ELUP) to be developed during the project's first year both for the Pacific and the Atlantic regions. These plans would identify areas of high environmental risks and contain other information necessary for MARENA and the MTUs to make decisions regarding environmental aspects of subprojects. To minimize environmental risks from decentralization, an environmental assessment process and mitigation plan at the municipal level, detailing the procedures that municipalities should adopt to screen out investments that pose high environmental risks or to include mitigating measures, was developed by INIFOM as part of the preparation for the proposed project. The procedures are described in the project's background document in the project file: " Sistema de Procedimientos Ambientales para la Gesti6n Ambiental Municipal". These procedures, once implemented, would apply not only to the municipalities eligible for the project, but to all municipalities in the country. Activities in the Atlantic pose higher environmental risks, thus they would only be initiated once the Environment and Land Use Plan for the Atlantic, including a delineation of the proposed Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor, is completed. Subprojects in the Atlantic would have to be consistent with this plan and with the Atlantic Biodiversity Corridor Strategy and would only start once the associated GEF project becomes effective.

MONITORING The establishment of an efficient project monitoring system is instrumental to assure the consistency of project activities, and in particular of the investment program, with the stated objectives. A set of monitoring indicators, based on the project's logical framework analysis, is shown in Table A 0. 1 through AI 0.7 and Figure 10. 1. The project monitoring system is separated in two distinct units: one dealing with the municipal development component implemented by INIFOM; and a second one focused on natural resource management and protection implemented by MARENA. The project monitoring system would be based on a Management Information System (MIS) with a database which organizes pertinent physical and financial information. A. Municipal Development Component This component relies heavily on a decentralized system of decision-making and management, involving a large number of small, diverse subprojects. Hence, since the ex ante determination of the pattern of project investment and other key parameters is not possible, effective supervision depends on the existence of a capable monitoring system. This system will provide information regarding the progress of the subproject in its different stages (e.g., subproject approval, procurement, implementation, and disbursement), types of projects approved and implemented, and verify that project activities are consistent with the guidelines, targeting methodology, and selection criteria included in the Operational Manual (Reglamento Operativo). This MIS would be managed with a decentralized database to be established by the MTU, and aggregated at the INIFOM regional and central levels. INIFOM would also disseminate lessons learned through monitoring among municipalities and communities. For each subproject, the MIS would record at least the following information: (1) a brief subproject description; (2) location by community and municipality; (3) number of beneficiaries and among them number of women and indigenous people; (4) cost of the subproject and co-financing including community contribution; (5) date of contract signing; (6) starting and finishing dates for the subproject; (7) an index of physical work carried out at each monitoring visit and a physical measure at completion (e.k. kms. of community road rehabilitated; wells built, area under erosion control, etc.); (8) acceptance by the community of the finished subproject; (9) name and address of community contact person; (10) subproject sustainability, effective use, and replicability.
