 NICARAGUA RURAL MUNICIPALITIES PROJECT ANNEX 12 ECONOMIC IMPACTS 1. INTRODUCTION Benefit estimation of investments in institutional strengthening, poverty alleviation and environmental protection is not simple. On the one hand, ex-post cross-country econometric studies have found time and again a clear positive relation between investments in those activities and countries' economic development (see for example recent Bank's World Development Reports on poverty, environment, health and infrastructure). On the other hand, ex-ante estimation of the benefits of a particular investment of that sort is fraught with difficulties, stemming from high levels of uncertainty, lack of engineering data on relationships between inputs and outputs, limited price information and widespread externalities. These difficulties are compounded in the proposed project because, given its demand driven nature, which investments will be actually implemented is unknown. Hence the purpose of this Annex is to more specifically identify project costs and benefits and to roughly estimate, as orders of magnitude, the economic impacts of the project from a subset of activities given assumptions of what kinds of subprojects will be demanded and implemented. 2. ECONOMIC BENEFITS There are three dimensions of economic impacts from the proposed project: (1) from decentralization; (2) from natural resource and environmental policy reform; and (3) from subprojects. The expected economic impacts from decentralization are primarily three: (a) reduction in costs of delivering public services relative to the costs of these services if they were managed centrally; (b) a better optimum (more efficient mix) of local investments relative to the mix accruing if decisions were taken by a centralized agency; and (c) improved community structures and thus increases in the social capital. The expected economic impacts from natural resource and environmental policy reform are primarily three: (a) economic efficiency gains from eliminating many spurious regulations on natural resource use; (b) reduction in the costs of governing due to increased government credibility from actually enforcing a clearer legal and policy framework than under the without project scenario; and (c) better intemalization of environmental extemalities by the public, private and NGO sectors. The expected economic impacts from subprojects are primarily four: (a) through leaming by doing and training reduction in the costs of municipalities and communities in identifying, preparing, implementing and operating subprojects; (b) improved decision-making by private farmers and other rural poor from the capacity building projects; (c) economic gains from enhanced environmental protection; and (d) economic surpluses from economic
 Annex 12 Economic Impacts Page 2 of 10 infrastructure and higher productivity from on-farm and off-farrn economic subsistence activities to be supported by the project. B. SUBPROJECTS Methodology Used. During preparation economic analysis focused only on a subset of those benefits: the economic impacts of the expected portfolio of environmental and productive subprojects. The rationale was that if this subset of benefits is sufficient to cover all economic project costs, the project makes economic sense and it is not necessary to estimate the other, more difficult to quantify benefits. Because sub-projects are demand driven and it is not known ex-ante what community and municipality choices will be, two estimates of sub- project demand were developed by polling municipal governments, NGOs and beneficiaries directly (see Annexes 1 and 3). Therefore, the present estimates should be regarded as an exercise, aiming only at giving an order of magnitude of the project's potential benefits. The exercise looks only to the more productive related components (environmental protection, rural infrastructure, and rural production) which together account for some 50% of expected total project costs. No benefit estimates are attempted for the other 50% of the project which would cover institutional strengthening activities and capacity building at the national and local level. Within each category a short list of possible subprojects was used to illustrate the potential economic benefits and the environmental and poverty alleviation achievements of the environmental protection, rural infrastructure and rural production components. The following types of subprojects were evaluated: (1) erosion control; (2) mangrove protection; (3) rural water; (4) rehabilitation of municipal and community roads; and (5) subsistence agriculture/livestock subprojects. Environmental Subprojects Erosion Control. Although soil erosion is to a large extent a natural process, its acceleration due to deforestation, agricultural practices, and other rural development activities (see Annex 2), can have detrimental consequences both at the farm level (reduced crop yields) and off-site (flooding, biodiversity losses, damage to infrastructure). Although this analysis focuses only on on-farm soil erosion impacts there is substantial anecdotal evidence that in the Pacific Region of Nicaragua off-site impacts of soil erosion are even more important, in particular through the damage to infrastructure (roads and irrigation systems) and respiratory disease due to volcanic dust from wind erosion. Agriculturally induced soil erosion and resulting crop losses have surfaced as major concerns in all the surveys carried out during project preparation. Available figures seem to confirm this concern. Soils in the project region are to a large extent young soils from volcanic origin, hence prone to erosion, particularly wind erosion, as a result of the region's predominant semiarid climate, with a long dry season. According to De Franco, et al (1993)1 soil losses in Leon and Chinandega agricultural areas range from a low 35 - 45 ton/ha/year, for permanent or semi-permanent crops, like rice or sugar, to 100 ton/halyear or more, in soils ' De Franco et al (1993) "Erosion and Economic Growth in Nicaragua" Central Bureau of Statistics, Oslo, and Instituto Centroamericano de Administraci6n de Empresas, Managua.
 Annex 12 Economic Impacts Page 3 of 10 devoted to annual crops such as beans, corn, sesame and cotton. Soil losses in recently deforested areas are higher. De Franco, et al (1993) provide detailed erosion figures and associated yield declines for six Nicaraguan regions, and eight different crops, from 1981 to 1991. Together with production and yields figures (from Nicaragua's MAG) they were used to calculate: (1) An average production value of US$179 per hectare/year. This is a weighted average based on production and yield figures for the six most important regional crops during 1993/94, valued at 1994 fann gate prices.2 (2) An average erosion induced yield loss of 1.5 % per hectare/year. This is also a weighted average, based on 1981 - 1991 erosion figures, and 1993/94 production figures. Considering that the regional harvested area in 1993/94 was approximately 200,000 ha, the estimates from (1) and (2) can be used to roughly calculate annual erosion related losses, and their present value over a multi-year period. The potential on-farm gains of soil erosion control are significant. Arresting soil erosion in the area currently under cultivation, over the next 20 years, would result in increased crops with a present value of US$ 52 million dollars, or US$ 23 per ha (at a 10% discount rate)3. According to estimations developed during project preparation, conservation costs could range from a low of US$ 81 dollars/ha (mostly cultivation and cropping changes, and the use of vegetation barriers) to a high of US$ 405 dollars/ha. Estimated on-farm benefits rule out the more expensive conservation methods. On the other hand, if an average cost figure of US$137 is used, 75% (US$4.3 million) of the project's environmental protection component would be enough to finance the protection of 27,400 ha, approximately 14% of the current crop area. This would entail benefits of the order of US$ 8.6 million, and a benefit-cost ratio of 2.0. Benefits would be significantly higher if future increases in rural production (the assumption is that production would continue at current levels except for gains from erosion controls) or off-farm benefits had been considered as well. These figures are only illustrative. A recent study conducted in Central America (Lutz, et al, 1994) suggests that, in many instances, this is not the case even when erosion control investments are provided at no cost. In Nicaragua, terraces were built on farns in the Lake Xolotan watershed, at no cost to the farmers, with the purpose of reducing flood hazards in Managua city. But since terraces interfered with cultivation practices, and did not result in perceived benefits to the farmer, they were soon destroyed. Given the demand driven nature of this project these problems would be avoided. 2 Hereafter "region" refers to both Le6n and Chinandega. 3 A manzana -mz- equals 0.74 hectare. Figures are net of incremental harvest costs. All USS figures are based on an exchange rate of 7.5 Nicaragua's Co. per US$ dollar. Hereafter all present value figures are based in a 20 year period and a 10% discount rate.
 Annex 12 Economic Impacts Page 4 of 10 Mangrove Protection. The larger portion of Nicaragua's mangrove is in the project's region, mostly in the Chinandega department. Although nearly 80% of the regions 84,700 hectare of mangrove have been declared protected area, they are actually highly intervened by small farmers and fishermen's activities (extraction of firewood, poles, shellfishes, shrimp larvae, and mangroves' bark), and the deforestation of large tracts of mangroves to install shrimp ponds, of which 7,000 hectares have already been granted, and authorization is pending for another 10,000 hectares.4 If the process of mangrove deterioration is not arrested, it will soon reduce the productivity of the very same activities that now breed on it, a process already at work in nearby countries such as Ecuador and Honduras. Unfortunately there is no comprehensive study on the economic value of Nicaragua's mangroves, which could guide the design of technical alternatives and the estimation of benefits.' In the meantime, available local and intemational experiences provide some evidence of what such benefits might be: (1) Families living from small-scale extractive activities in Chinandega's mangroves report an annual income ranging from US$ 1,000 to US$ 2,000 net of production costs, based on a harvesting area of approximately 10 ha. per family (an annual economic value per mangrove ha/year of US$ 100 - 200 dollars). (2) Due to the incipient shrimp pond production, larvae collection has been modest, averaging some US$ 33,000 dollars a year, but if the full potential 30,000 ha. of ponds were in place they could represent a market for shrimp larvae of some US$ 4 million dollars a year, or US$ 133 per mangrove ha/year. Since current prices paid for wild larvae --US$ 2.5 per thousand are half the cost of laboratory produced larvae, this figure could be considered representative of the net benefits provided by the ecosystem supply of wild larvae. Unfortunately there is no indication to assess if this would be a sustainable larvae's capture level. (3) The 1993 harvest of shrimp off Nicaragua's Pacific coast amounted to 715,500 kgs, 90% of which was exported at an average price of US$ 1.2 per kg. It seems that current capture is well below its sustainable level, considering that studies of shrimp productivity in coastal Asian waters off mangrove areas suggest that 1 hectare of mangrove can be the early breading ground of as much as 862 kgs of adult see shrimps (with a corresponding gross value of US$ 4,950 dollar). It should be noticed, though, that early larvae capture would reduce this productivity figures and, furthermore the region's mangrove are already highly deteriorated. Also it is not clear that the Asia figures can be extrapolated to the Nicaragua case. (4) Studies of several Caribbean areas have estimated net harvest values ranging from a low US$ 50 dollars/halyear where only traditional extractive activities take 4 Although several references mentioned 7,000 ha of existing ponds, those in production seem to be only a fraction --around 250 ha. to 300 ha.-- considering 1993 figures for shrimp production -- 138,198 kgs - and average yields of 545 kgs/hectare. 5 In 1995 two small projects with international support began working on sustainable development projects in region's mangrove areas.
 Annex 12 Economic Impacts Page 5 of 10 place, up to a high US$ 1,550 dollars/ha/year where intensive shrimp ponds are in place (Hamilton/Snedaker, 1984).6 Considering the high range of extractive activities reported in the region's mangroves - -US$ 200 per ha/year of net benefits-- the net present value of an hectare of mangrove over a 20 year period, would be around US$ 1,700-1,900. With a conservative mangroves' deforestation figure of 3.5% per year, the present value of potential losses of mangrove deforestation over a 20 years period would represent about US$33.8 million. It should be remembered that these are "potential" net benefits, that only would accrue if and when the mangrove is harvested on a sustainable base. Costs of conservation cum sustainable production projects in mangrove areas varies widely, with some estimates developed during project preparation as low as US$ 70/hectare and two current projects in the area featuring costs around US$ 500/hectare. Allocating 25% of the project's environmental component (US$1.5 million) to mangrove protection could result in the conservation of some 3,000 hectare of mangrove, with a present value of potential benefits of about US$ 3.6 million and a benefit cost ratio of 2.4. Municipal and Community Infrastructure Subprojects. Both provision of drinking water and roads improvernent have been singled out as the most important infrastructure developments to ameliorate the plight of rural poor in Nicaragua (World Bank, 1995). Therefore they are used below as examples of the activities that could be funded by the project's infrastructure subprojects (US$ 7.4 million). Rural water supply. According to end of 1993 figures, over 70% of Nicaragua's rural poor lacked access to piped water, inside or outside their houses, or access to a public standpipe. Almost all rural poor lacked any sewer system and over 156,000 rural poor (some 27,000 families) lacked a water connection or access to a public standpipe. The high social and economic costs of this situation have been repeatedly highlighted: "...children in households without water and sanitation are twice more likely to be malnourished than children in households with water and sanitation.. Low coverage of water and sanitation services.. explain why diarrhea and vector borne diseases are still the main causes of morbidity and mortality in Nicaragua" (World Bank, 1995, p.ii). Poor people in rural areas pay for trucks delivered water more then ten times the urban water rates: US$ 2 to US$ 3.3 per cubic meter, compared to an average of US$ 0.16 per cubic meter paid in urban areas. Considering that, on average, poor rural dwellers without water services use one hour a day for water collection, each family is investing the equivalent of US$ 110 per year to obtain a very limited supply of poor quality water (this figure is based on a salary of US$ 0.30 per hour, that is the lower end of hourly earnings of poor rural females). Considering an opportunity cost correction factor for rural labor in Nicaragua of 0.6, the economic cost of water collection at present per family-year would be US$ 66. 6 Hamilton L & Snedaker S. (1994) "Handbook for Mangrove Area Management". IUCN, UNECO, UNEP, EWC, Gland.
 Anncx 12 Economic Impacts Page 6 of 10 Costs of rural water provision vary with the characteristics of the site and the pretended level of service. Cost of house connection to piped systems (gravity or power pumped water systems) ranges from US$ 45 to US$ 100 per person. Providing individual or communal manual pumps is much cheaper, with per capita costs in the range of US$ 10 to US$ 30. Using US$ 50 as an intermediate value (US$ 290 per family), providing water to all the non-served rural poor in Leon and Chinandega, would cost US$ 7.8 million. Assuming that US$ 5.9 million would be spent in community rural water projects, the present value of costs including 5% per year of operation and maintenance would add up to US$ 8.2 million, compared with US$ 11.0 million of family savings. The benefit cost ratio would be 1.3. Rehabilitation of Rural Municipal and Community Roads. Between 1980 and 1991 Nicaragua lost 3,500 km of rural roads, almost 20% of its 1980 road system. Bad rural roads have been blamed for agricultural production losses, high transport costs, and hence high spreads between market prices and farmn prices (see World Bank, 1995, vol 1). During 1994, wholesale prices were 39% higher than farm-gate prices, for a weighted average of the six more important regional crops. Le6n and Chinandega have 2,500 Km of roads, of which 950 are rural roads, suitable for dry season use only. The costs of upgrading community and municipality roads to an around-the-year use standard range between US$ 800 to US$ 1,500 per km. To revamp the thousand kilometers of existing rural roads and assuming the higher figure cost, would cost about US$ 1.5 million (some 20% of the project's rural infrastructure component). If better roads could reduce the spread between farm gate and wholesale prices by 5% (from 39% to 37%), that would represent an extra income to local farmers in the order of US$ 2.9 dollars/mz/year, as much as US$ 0.8 million per year considering the current harvested area.7 Over 20 years, and considering the higher investment cost (US$ 1,500 per km) plus 5% annual maintenance cost, the present value of total cost would amount to US$ 2.1 million, compared to the present value of benefits of US$ 6.7 million and a benefit-cost ratio of 3.2 Increases in farm-gate prices are not the only result from better rural roads. According to the World Bank poverty report, poor rural roads, together with lack of storage and treatment facilities, contributed to the loss of as much as 20% of the corn and 8% of the beans harvested in Nicaragua (World Bank, 1995 vol I p.42). Better rural roads would result in an increase in production and a decrease in crop losses. Hence the figures quoted are a low estimate of the benefits accruing from better rural roads. Community Productive Subprojects Each category of municipal investments would have, directly or indirectly, a positive impact on rural production. The category of municipal subprojects specifically aims at increasing rural production from poor farmers. In total about US$7.4 million of community productive investments could be financed through the project. Their financial and economic costs and benefits are addressed in this section. POVERTY ALLEVIATION The project focus is on environmental protection and poverty alleviation. References have already been made to both issues in relation to the environmental protection and to the rural water components. Some further comments on the extent and composition of poverty, and on the potential poverty alleviation impact of financing rural production follow. According to the World Bank 1995 study, Nicaragua's poverty line as of November 1993 was Co 214.47 of per capita monthly income (with an extreme poverty line at Co. 101.32 of per capita monthly income). Since the average rural family size is 5.8 persons per household, the rural family income poverty line, adjusted to 1995 prices would be al Co. 18,700 family/year or US$ 2,487 /family/year.8 As of the end of 1993, Nicaragua had a total population of 4 million people. Le6n and Chinandega accounted for 702,000 people of which 312,000 people lived in rural areas. At that time, more than half Nicaragua's population was under the poverty line, and almost 20% of the population was in extreme poverty. Country-wide, poverty is concentrated in rural areas. This pattern is even more marked in Ledn and Chinandega (see Table A 12.4) 8 The poverty line is defined as the total per capita monthly expenditure at which an individual obtains the minimum daily caloric requirements. The extreme poverty line is defined as the level of per capita monthly food expenditures required to obtain the daily minimum caloric requirement (World Bank, 1995, vo. I p.2). Hereafter figures for poor population are inclusive of extremely poor population.

Although the majority of Nicaragua's rural poor households are peasants, only half their income comes from farming and related activities9 with another third coming from wages. The US$ 6.7 million that according to demand estimates are expected to be channeled to community productive subprojects could benefit between 1,450 and 10,000 such families. If the higher figure were achieved it would signify benefiting 25% of the region's poor farmers. Comparatively, in 1993 only 720 poor farmers in the region received some kind of assistance (averaging $ 560 dollars). Reaching 25% of the region poor farmers is probably difficult. According to some estimates, for a farm to produce an annual income of US$ 2,500 dollars/year, it should have between 4 and 14 ha in production (depending on the crop mix). But the majority of poor farmers have holdings of less than 3 hectares. Significant increases in small farm sizes would be called for in order to achieve above poverty incomes, based solely in the farm production. On the other hand, farming is currently a marginal source of income for a considerable number of poor peasants. Thus the project includes in the category of community productive subprojects non-farm investments, such as microenterprises and small processing facilities, which would be a way to complement, or in some cases substitute for, farn income, in order to help a larger number of rural poor rise above poverty incomes. 4. doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Rural Municipalities Project are to reduce rural poverty and to improve natural resources management. These objectives can be narrowed down more specifically to the following: 1) to establish a mechanism based on municipal governments and community organizations for reducing rural poverty through rural investment in economic infrastructure, improved natural resource management and small-scale communal productive activities; 2) to ensure that central government institutions acquire the capacity to provide a coherent overall framework for natural resource policy making and enforcement, accounting for global, national and regional environmental priorities; and 3) to promote the long-term integrity of a biological corridor along the Atlantic slope of Nicaragua, conserving key global biodiversity values. To meet these objectives, the project will have the following three components: 1) rural municipalities development, including institutional development, information, participation, training and grants; 2) natural resources policies and institutions involving institutional development and an inter-institutional technical assistance program; and 3) Atlantic biodiversity corridor (GEF), which will include land use and biodiversity planning, monitoring and evaluation and a financial mechanism to promote the sustainability of the corridor.
